reviewText:
some people might not get the importance of mods in this game,you shouldn't expect to have a lot of fun with this game if you dont play with mods on, because they add so much content and interesting scenarios to the game.

in my honest opinion, it's a pretty good game, you'll probably get a few laughs and good times out of it, also seeing as how you can play with buddies split-screen, but you will definately also rage at it once in a while.
here's the website of the devs and where you'll find the mods (mods are in the fan forums section); http://datarealms.com

i'll list a couple that people should definately check out if they want to play this game here;

there are two kinds of mods that you'll find in the fan forums; mods and scenes. scenes are general scenarios, such as a base assault or an entirely redone campaign. mods are, well, mods. factions, weapons, you name it. someone even made a filter to make the game dark and gritty, and someone made tiberium from command and conquer.

-Mods-

http://forums.datarealms.com/viewtopic.php?f=61&t=25544
Warhammer 40K imperium of man: a massive mod that adds pretty damn overpowered soldiers and weapons into the game, but not so op that it's no fun to play them, you can feel very powerful with the soldiers, but they're not indestructible, and they're fairly expensive. one thing i should note is that with the soldiers with jetpacks you can do a dash in the direction your mouse is pointing by pressing shift+up.
there's additional instructions for how to make the individual factions other than the standard blue space marines available on the forum page.

http://forums.datarealms.com/viewtopic.php?f=61&t=11062
Unitec: *note: it's very important that you download the 1.05 compatible version that weegee posted on page 136 of the thread. otherwise it wont work, unless you're using an older version of the game.*
the unitec mod is really amazing, it adds 3 inredible factions into the game which each have a big variety of weapons to use, it's really incredible how much this mod has to offer. i'd like to note that you can enable hidden weapons in Unitec.rte/Devices/Weapons.ini and change the ones you dont see in the in-game menu to either 1 or 0 (depending on what it's already set to)

http://forums.datarealms.com/viewtopic.php?f=61&t=17247
Darkstorm: very cool mod with quite a few interesting devices that will light your enemies ablaze (the fire on them will light other units that walk into them on fire as well) or freeze enemies to death. the warhammer mod uses this fire mechanic as in their mod as well.

http://forums.datarealms.com/viewtopic.php?f=61&t=18120
SAW: you should really just take a look at the thread, the artwork that's been done of this is incredible, and it's fairly satisfying to use as well.

http://forums.datarealms.com/viewtopic.php?f=61&t=20028
Kettenkrad's wehrmacht: this mod. this. mod. it's nazi and absolutely fabulous. i've seen tanks and artillery as well in this mod, but i think they were in earlier versions of it. it's worth a try to install earlier versions of it and see if they still work. i'd also like to post and additional mod for this one, since it fits very, very well. yes indeed, 'tis undead hitler. (none's post) http://forums.datarealms.com/viewtopic.php?f=75&t=24174

-Scenes-

http://forums.datarealms.com/viewtopic.php?f=24&t=45538
ssl assault: if you're bored of the good ol' bunker breaches, this is a brand new, easy to install scene which introduces 3 new ones (not under bunker breach, but under a new one called ssl assault 1-3) the first two of which being assaults against the coalition with no counterattacks, and the third being an attack against techion with a lot of counterattack once you reach exit the first building you go into.

http://forums.datarealms.com/viewtopic.php?f=24&t=29714
Cortex Shock: HOLY COW THIS IS GOOD, i almost forgot this one, it's an adventure scenario that puts you through various fairly hard levels, get your game face on for this one. there is some mod compatibility in this, but it'll be better explained on the mod page.

http://forums.datarealms.com/viewtopic.php?f=24&t=31063
SHIELD: Under Siege: this is a scene that requires the Unitec mod i listed, it's a fantastic campaign with 14 levels that each has unique oblectives and hardcore gameplay, very very fun, but be careful not to lose your units, you will instantly lose. the mod is discontinued, but there should be enough content to make anyone happy. i very much recommend getting this mod.

http://forums.datarealms.com/viewtopic.php?f=24&t=12807
http://forums.datarealms.com/viewtopic.php?f=24&t=17619
http://forums.datarealms.com/viewtopic.php?f=24&t=25113
Prison Escape 1-3: i really think you should just start playing this without any other words from me. 3 fantastic missions with an incredible feat of scripting at the end.

http://forums.datarealms.com/viewtopic.php?f=24&t=31383
Unmapped Lands 2: this scene is very simple to play, but it can also get very long the longer you play, because the AI gets so much gold that he simply never runs out when he's attacking you. there's a manual in the thread for how to play the games.

and that's it. i hope you enjoy playing with mods, since i certaintly have done. there's a bunch more mods on the forums that you can find, but i'll leave it there.

reviewText:
This is the best game with a Metacritic score of 44 I've ever played.

Hell, this is one of the most compelling games I've ever played, period. I never got into the metagame, but the individual battles -- where you're digging for loot so you can buy wobbly inverse-kinematics-y troops who arrive in unreliable crashy spaceships and stomp uncertainly across a mushy, shifting battlefield (partially composed of the corpses of previous troops) and then blast off in jetpacks, sometimes splattering against walls, so they can have a chance at maybe putting a bullet in the head of a flamethrower-wielding crash test dummy -- are CRAZY and WONDERFUL.

No description can do justice to the joy of crashing a tiny high-speed rocket full of bombs into an enemy stronghold, or sneaking a lone, powerful (but, again, VERY wobbly) robotic commando through a labyrinthine base equipped with nothing but a plasma pistol and a grenade launcher. This is one of those games where failure is every bit as exciting as success. And the mod community is very active, so if you want to play as a wobbly, two-dimensional Gordon Freeman or Emperor Palpatine, those options are available to you. Cortex Command is a game about physics and glorious stupidity. It's a game about ricocheting a sniper rifle shot off a set of doors and accidentally knocking the rifle out of your own hands. It's a game where, when you're sent to retrieve an object, you sweat the ENTIRE TIME because you're afraid you'll drop the object down a hole or accidentally jetpack yourself right out of the level while holding it.

This game is bliss.

reviewText:
Awkward, Clunky, and often doesn't work as expected. Normally this would make it a bad game, but you just haven't lived until you've seen a drop ship veer just a little bit too far to the right and cause a 15 man allied platoon to break out into a Decapitation Conga Line with the power of its white-hot main thruster, then immediately thereafter crash into the pile of corpses it just created, explode like it was full of nitroglycerin, AND THEN launch one of it's blast doors across the map, over the mountains of gibs and fallen friends and foes alike, right into YET ANOTHER allied dropship, which then starts the whole process all over again.

Mix in mods and add rains of refrigerators, cluster-nukes and even your very own custom gun that presumably will fire a wall of bullets that creates so much recoil that the guy who fired it instantly sublimates for extra fun.




Also it's got some neato mechanics and gameplay, but you likely won't notice past the endless downpour of dropship parts and chunks of clone-torso.

reviewText:
Don't be fooled by my hours, I played the Non-Steam version quite a while.

A lot of people seem to be confused by this game. They probably expected some epic story mode or intense multiplayer battles, and end up disappointed because CC doesn't have these features. But it has something different: An incredible sandbox experience.

Do you want to know how I play it? I load up a map of Skirmish Defense, enable unlimited gold and that my brain can be placed anywhere, then build an unbreachable subterranean bunker and start the game. Now the real fun begins. Wave after wave of enemies will try to tunnel a way to my brain, but this task is a bit complicated by the fact that I constantly drop crates filled with pineapple grenades and molotov cocktails on their heads and watch their bodies explode into gore.
Soon, the whole battlefield is covered in body parts and debris. The never ending waves of enemies have to crawl trough a horrible mess of blood and flesh from their fallen brethren, only to be ripped apart by the next crate bomb. If this gets boring, I set up a Sniper with a high powered Anti-Vehicle rifle on a hilltop. It is just too damn entertaining to shoot out a drop ship's engines and then finish the remaining crew with a single, multiple-body-penetrating shot.

The completely desctructible environment is just so awesome to mess with. When you fire bullets at the ground, you can see them traveling through the dirt and coming to a halt. The game even takes into account what weapon was used - bullets of rifles will bury much deeper than the ones of pistols.
This also introduces some interesting mechanics in terms of bunker design. Depending on the angle from where the shot was fired, a bullet will either bounce off a wall or penetrate it.
Exploding grenades produce shrapnel that rips apart even the toughest enemy. There is even a Chainsaw Gun. Guess what it does. Yes, it fires Chainsaws.

The only problem with Cortex Command are the lazy developers. This game has been in development forever, and nothing significant has changed. The devlog is updated twice a year max, and it's been ages since the last release. This makes the 20$ pricetag feel like a rip-off, since you're buying an unfinished product that probably will never be finished.

If you can pick it up at sale, though... go for it!

reviewText:
Down to my last guy, missing half my health and completely unarmed, facing an armored Coalition soldier with a minigun. I rocketed into him with my jetpack, knocked the gun from his hands, and then picked it up. We stared at each other for a moment just before I emptied the whole clip into him. Then I hid on a tower top with a scavenged grenade launcher, and used it to take down a whole platoon and a dropship before I finally bled to death. It was a good day.

Most of my hours playing this have been offline or with a standalone copy. As a physics sandbox, CC is unmatched. The campaign is fun, but just starting a skirmish and dropping bombs on things never gets old. Unlike so many titles nowadays, there is nothing to unlock, no experience to gain, no hook to keep you playing, and yet I keep coming back to it because it's just enjoyable. Like playing with toys when you were a kid. Not since the original Unreal Tournament have I spent so much time on a game simply because of the moment to moment fun factor.

Also, the workshop is populated with great mods. If you can stomach a certain amount of wonkiness and the occasional crash, the game is absolutely worth it.

11/10 would sacrifice Derek for no reason again

reviewText:
This is a game you'll either love or hate. the controls can be frustrating, the ai stupid, buggy as hell, and unpredictable. BUT! if you can stck with it through all the hardship it is a very rewarding and hilarious game filled with loads of chaos and laughter. The modding community has been slowing down of late, but there are still many great mods which add exponential replayablity to this great game.

The steam community feature is a bit bugged on it though, and I didn't always run it directly through steam so my time on it is actually about several hundred hours more than that.

Also for you modders the game is very basic LUA and sprite graphics so it is incredibly easy to mod. I have hardly any script experience with lua and even i can do it.

So if you have patience, and don't mind s little bit of frustration you might enjoy this game a lot.

reviewText:
First of all, don't let the Metacritic score decieve you, it deserves waaaay better than a 44.

This game reminds me of those good, old flashgames where you pick your clunky, pixelated troops and let them roam around the map to invade and destroy the enemy's base, i loved those!
Well this game is one of those, but sooo much better in every way!
This game focusses on building your own bunker to protect your dissembodied brain from the hostiles invading it.
You pick your rooms, walls and barricades from a wide variety of different models and easily place them down.
Then you choose your starting units from a large list, ranging from zombies to T-1000-ish killerbots which you can customise freely to wield a huge amount of different weapons.
Once you've done that, you can switch to any of those units and controll them untill it gets eliminated or you switch to another unit. You can also put it in patroll mode to guard your base, sentry mode to guard a specific area and brain hunt where it will go towards the enemy's bunker and find its way to the brain. And if needed, call down a V2 rocket piloted by a drunk pilot who will probably crash, but still deliver your fully-outfitted troops roughly where you wanted them (or you just lob them from space in a box and let it crash a few metres deep in the sand, forcing them to crawl out of the gaping hole while hostiles throw molotov cocktail inside, fun times!)

I must say, this game is very fun to play, Its simple, creative and action packed!
Hell, i had a soldier once who faced off agains three other robots, his legs got shot of and his rifle got destroyed, so he switched to his pistol and killed all three of them before bleeding out.
It's these awesome moments that make this game so great! Shooting down a dropship and witnessing the soldiers under it getting flattend by it or a squad heroicly fighting off hordes of crash-test dummies while trying to block their entrypoint with a concrete launcher, and all of this happened in those few hours i've played!
Worshop makes it even better, adding in units from other games like Warhammer 40K or Halo makes it much more interessting, even adding in a few new maps is always fun!

The only downsides i've encountered is the clunky menu, the poor UI, lacking tutorial and the fact that there is no Free camera mode.
There barely is a UI besides the circular hold-the-right-mousebutton one which is a little confusing at first, the tutorial is very minimum, but you learn the basics of the game pretty fast anyways. And the camera, well, thats permanently focussed on the unit you are using, so no looking around the place, which is annoying if you hear a dropship nearby, but you can't see it.

But for my final verdict, this game is a must-buy for people who like customising their own troops individualy, who like games that tell stories about how badass the units were in that one battle against those 100 crabs and for those who just like building giant, trap-filled bunkers for the CPU to breach (which it will, he'll just dig into the brain's bunker right away)

I give it a score of 8.5/10, take that Metacritic!

reviewText: In a world where humans have transferred their brains into robot husks and an interplanetary gold rush begins, players must make the choice of either flying a rocket filled with bombs into the enemy brain or simply rush in with a dude with a very large gun.\n\nCortex Command is one of those oddly unique games that are just meant for modding. 80% of the game's content is stuff you'll find in the workshop and on the data realms forums. As for gameplay, it's interesting to say the least. The game is definitely not a realistic combat simulation, but it definitely uses jetpacks in ways they've never been used before. Keep the throttle on for too long and you'll find yourself zooming across the map at the speed of sound. As for actual combat, it's thought out and entertaining. Things such as bullet weight and velocity play a good part in battle; a pistol's bullets will literally bounce off enemies if they're too far away, while a sniper rifle is heavy to carry but can penetrate armor from a good distance. You'll soon find that when you build your base you'll be putting down heavily armored juggernauts with rocket launchers and LMGs since you don't need them to move much (you'll also find weight is a real hinderance since jetpacks are the only real way to move) while your assault troops will probably just have that one remote-detonation-grenade launcher you think is really cool. While most battles have the simple objective kill the enemy brain"
date: there are alternative game modes available in the base game
recommended: like surviving with one troop for a set amount of time or holding down a base being attacked by dummies.\n\nCortex Command isn't for everyone
hoursPlayed: but if you don't mind a random decapitation becuase you hit the roof from time to time and you're not super serious about realism then this game will be worth the money."

reviewText:
The AI is clunky and buggy, the faction weapons are unbalanced in terms of price and damage, the maps can get repetitive, and it can be laggy at times.

Through all of that, the game is amazing. You can have great fun bombing the enemy with crabs, sending your troops on suicide runs, or surviving against waves and waves of enemies assaulting your base, with your gold supplies dwindling and your troops dying by the second. And don't even get me started on how much mods make this game even better.

Once you get the hang of it and get past its many quirks and bugs, it's really enjoyable. The physics are good, you can destroy literally everything in the game and shoot limbs off of enemies. With certain mods the replay value can make you want to play it over and over.
Note the game IS buggy and lacks a lot of polish which might err some people.

reviewText:
This is by far my favorite game, it has given many more play than any other game I have ever played, barring Civ and DOTA 2. I attribute this fact to the fact that it can be played over and over again without feeling stale, this is because it has an amazing modding community, with mods ranging from a new weapon, to completly changing the game.

Pros:
Replayability
Great base game
Despite the updates being rare, they do still come, and still provide new content
Slight sense of humor (Look Sir, free crabs!)
Great modding community

Cons:
Fairly costly
Occasionly crashes (Checking the game cache works wonders)
Long loading starting loading screen (This happens when too many mods are installed)
Updates are rare

Attributes:
RTS and a Shooter in one
Terrain destruction
Pixel graphics
Digging

reviewText: Cortex Command is a game I really enjoy. It has complex strategy, great game mechanics, and replayability. The biggest draw of CC is it's sandbox like nature, allowing you to play around, or give yourself a challenge. The biggest flaw with CC is that it really doesn't have much to do in it, it's more of a game that you'll pick up and play from time to time than a deep game you'll spend hours with. That said, it never really gets old unless you play really often, it has dedicated mod support to keep things interesting, and a great multiplayer mode. It may not be deep enough to be worth $20, but if you are willing to pay that, you'll find a solid game that will stay fun for a long time, so long as you don't wear it out. Cortex Command gets a 7.5/10

reviewText:
I couldn't honestly recommend spending money on this game.  I believed the latest vid from the developer, stating that a lot of previous issues have been fixed etc, and so picked it up for $6 in a steam sale, but to be honest it must have been pretty bad before if this is supposed to be significantly improved.

It definitely has potential: the combat could be fun if it wasn't so unbalanced, and the destruction/debris is nice.

The split-screen mode is one of the main reasons I picked it up.  A friend of mine who loves quirky indie games was coming over for the evening and this looked perfect.  We're used to playing a fair share of alpha/beta/unfinished Public Domain games where bugs are often part of the charm, but even this was too much for us and we gave up after about an hour.  I've since played it a little more on my own to see if we missed something, but as hard as I tried I couldn't feel anything but frsutration when playing this.

If you can figure out how to work around the weird bugs, the swampy controls, and the terrible GUI, then you might like it.  In the interest of fairness, I should say that I haven't tried any of the mods.  I read the other reviews on here and they all seem to agree that you need to try mods to get the most out of this, but my issues were with core things like controls and the single player campaign, which I doubt any mods would address,

reviewText:
When I first grabbed the game, I was expecting so much more. I had watched videos and done a little bit of research, and the game simply looked amazing for what it was. A unique side scrolling take on RTS.

When I actually got to hop in the game however, things went bad fast.

First off, learning the controls, even with the assistance of the tutorial was a pain. They only explain the bare minimum in how you can switch out to other units under your influence, and how to control them on a basic level. They tell you nothing of how you're supposed to actually use the unit, or how to activate its various AI scripts and what they actually do. The UI is bare minimum, you have to dig and test everything out on your own just to figure out things that should be presented directly, or have better in game descriptions.

While actually controlling your units, you'll find they are slow and terribly clunky. Even the faster/lighter units feel that way, and there's simply no way around. Heavy units are a literal nightmare to move around the map. With heavier units you'll find it almost impossible to reach certain areas, forcing you to use easily killed light units for everything, and only equipping them with the absolute bare minimum to assault the enemy. Attempting to use the AI scripts usually just forces them to saunter off to their deaths, they end up firing into the air blindly or never returning fire, while the enemy computer controlled units decimate your forces from half a mile away with a pistol.

While all the equipment and units you can call down are interesting, you'll find yourself most times just calling down basic units due to the cost to protect yourself, while the opponent seems to have near infinite resources he can call on. Even when you have a ton of money it seems to run out in seconds, where there's seem to have no end, even on the easier settings. That and the fact you'll notice the enemy AI is quite crafty in going after your controller unit/brain. Assassinating him from impossible angles, or simply just scuicide bum rushing you, while your idiot AI forces stand there and watch slack jawed, even is they are on sentry/defense mode.

There are a number of mods out there that can expand the gameplay, adding modes, areas, new factions and weapons and other things. Some of them are quite excellent, and it's to bad there was such a great modding community for this game, but the developer half ♥♥♥♥♥ it for about 10 years. Yep, that's right. This game was 10 years in development before seeing a full" version launch. Looking at the game now you'd probably be wondering where the full version is. It feels much more like a late alpha build
date: or very early beta.\n\nLike I said
recommended: it's such a shame there was such a passionate modding community

reviewText:
I bought this game off humble bundle back in early alpha.  I loved the promise of wacky robots fighting, blowing up in hilarious ways, procedural destruction, all that jazz.

I've waited a very long time for that promise to become a reality, and I am officially bitter.

Fast forward to today and you have the developer in his snazzy new video making more promises and explaining how he was the inspiration for Minecraft and how the steam launch was a miscommunication and he's getting back on track, all while wearing a tee-shirt marketing his next game to you at twice the price.

Here's a thought:  Demonstrate that you *can* make a game by actually finishing the first project before taking on an even more ambitious project and overselling that.  At least they're telling people on the PP forums not to buy it if they don't like bare bones engines, and I'd tend to agree and recommend the same for anyone looking to buy this.

reviewText:
Yes, it might have taken 10 years to 'finish'.
Yes, it might have a slapped on metagame to give it a 'released' look.
Yes, the game can be a serious performance hog.

HOWEVER, this is one of the most fun Worms inspired physics sidescroller shooters you will ever play. Interesting story concepts, excellent art and beautiful spriting, very fun and nice feeling guns, and loads of downloadable as well as createable missions, as well as the moddability.

Can be priced a bit high, most of the time, but I love it.

reviewText:
I've never been drawn into the game's campaign mode, nor really cared about multiplayer.

However, I could setup a base and shoot down dropships all day long. The pixel-perfect, destructable physics are a joy to watch, and surviving wave after wave with a variety of weapons is a constant source of entertainment.

It's a quirky game, and feels unfinished. But there's a core gameplay nugget in there that never gets old. If you're willing to make your own fun, sandbox style, this is a gem in the rough.

reviewText: I had the early alpha version of this game from humble indie bundle 2 in 2010. I thought it was a great game. It only had two levels, no full screen (or generally 'settings' of any nature), and skeleton gameplay mechanics, but it was very fun and I played it for weeks. It is now five years later, the game is STILL in an early state (even though its official release date was a couple years ago), and aparently all it does now is jump around for a moment, freeze up and crash.\n\nI'm not recommending this game because it is clearly an abandoned project. It is a great design, really, but unfortunately also not happening, so you'll just be throwing your money away. I'm lucky I got it in the steam winter sale for only a couple bucks. We'd be luckier still if another company would take over and resume development. Unless that happens, you're betting off skipping this tragedy.

reviewText:
So, here's the thing.  I have cortex command.  I play it a fair amount.  It's got some fun elements.  So, why the negative review?


This game never really finished development.  The game was very very cool as a concept when it was first released, but the UI is as bad as it has always been, there are frequent bugs, winning is pretty formulaic v. AI, and there are severe problems with multi.  The underlying concepts?  Fun.  The implementation?  Still incomplete.  Felt like something that got rushed to release with some minor new releases once the creator got bored.

reviewText:
Got this game in a Humble Bundle. I really wanted to like it, because it has a lot of originality. Unfortunately it seems to be very unoptimized, with lots of people having trouble getting playable performance on many hardware configurations. It also lacks focus, with each of the game modes (campaign, sandbox, challenge) being fairly thin on content. Worst of all, it is full of game-breaking glitches.

To top it all off, the author seems to have abandoned it to work on another game (Cave Vehicle Engine or somesuch) and has in any case been extremely poor at communicating with the game's community. The only fans left of this game on its forums are suffering from Stockholm Syndrome, and flame anyone who criticizes the game or the author's lack of devotion to it and/or the community.

This game will not be worth playing until the author releases the source code so that the community can do what he doesn't care enough to do.

reviewText:
If you're looking for a single player game, do not buy this. While it can be fun alone, it doesn't offer enough content in the base game to justify a $20 purchase.

That being said.

Cortex Command is best played with at least 2 people, all with controllers, on a large screen. Featuring somewhat janky but suprisingly tight platforming and even-jankier base-building mechanics

On top of that there's tons of mods to choose from to make it more challenging, or more funny, more hectic, mostly in the form of faction mods.

If you do buy this, do me a favor: buy a few dozen crabs (they're free), throw them into a drop crate, and plop it anywhere.

reviewText: This is a good game for maybe 2.50 but the controls are a nightmare. I just came from playing a match where you have to evacuate a brain from a base. I didnt know they uped the price to $20 (seeing how I got this in a humble bundle a while ago) but the fact is that this game isnt worth the $20... at all.

reviewText:
OVERALL
Mixed Feelings:  6/10
Fun at times, workshop support (Big plus for providing additional content), and an interesting concept, unfortunately suffers from crashes, gameplay is clunky, and it doesn't bring much to the table after the first hour or so. Would recommend on a sale.

+Active workshop community
+Easy to mod, limited built-in editor
+Cool idea, can be fun once you get used to the game
+Everything is destructible
+Base construction
+Good sound design
+Can setup soldier presets
~Either your unable to drop multiple soldiers at once, or I'm just unable to find the way to do that. Game doesn't inform the player about everything you can or cannot do.
~Pixel graphics. Well made, but if it's not your thing, your experience may suffer
~Jetpacks are a viable tactic for disarming enemies, but feels like a way around from proper movement pathing. (Characters get stuck on terrain easy. Jetpack seems like the only way to move effectively)
-$20 seems overpriced for what this game brings to the table.
-Base construction could be more user-friendly
-Suffers from random crashes
-Music volume becomes very loud when creating a new campaign, despite it being set to 1
-UI is lackluster
-Lots of needless trial and error
-Soldier controls take some time to get used to, but the cursor being tied to the camera can be dizzying
-Not enough feedback for the user
-> No total cost for bunker contruction when designing your own bunker, better off using auto build
-> Trial-and-error is the only way to figure out the campaign features, such as base building, attacking, funds, et cetera.
-Movement is finicky, it's easy to get caught up on the terrain.

reviewText:
I really like this game.

While still technically an alpha, or beta, it's still pretty fun. Multiplayer can only be played using the same computer, (with gamepads, or a wonky keyboard system).

The balance, while still being tweaked, is pretty good, you have a faction for everyone, too. even if they aren't finished yet.

The modding community is wonderful, adding new missions, different campaigns, new factions, new weaponry, soldiers, blah blah, really good community for modding.

Overall, yeah, I'd totally buy this game again, although, please note, the game is probably gonna be finished" in..like

reviewText: This is an extremely amped up 2D game that depends on the modding community. The metacritic score was likely formulated in an early build and without considering the mods. For example Gamespy said, In a way
date: Cortex Command seems like it's asking for a lot of concessions because
hoursPlayed: it still feels like an unfinished game."\n\nAnother example is what IGN said
voteText: "Not COD. 5/10." Just kidding. But seriously screw IGN. If you played only what IGN said was worth playing -- could you imagine?\n\nTo explain how ridiculous it is to review this game without taking the mods into account I will say this. If I recall back when I played on Build 23 the game itself was like 50-60 MB in size and the mods were nearly 3 GB. That's like playing Skyrim with 700 GB worth of mods. This is an Indie game that has it's own standards and priorities that diverge
helpfulPercent: tremendously
votesHelpful: from that of AAA titles. There are so many games that seek to limit the player into a narrow and limited vision that a couple developers had. This game is not like that.\n\nI think if all you play is the currently popular games then this game will be an empowering experience for you. This is a game that is wide open for you to change. reviewText: Movement is awkward, but as you play the game that becomes less of a problem. The sad thing is the Meta score doesn't do this game justice. At the time of its review alot of the features were not polished thus resulting in a horrible score. This game is great for those who like games like Battlezone and Mount and Blade. A combination of strategy and action. Very similar Battlezone(limited resources and the ability to control any unit) for you old timers looking for a game of a similar flavour. Problem is without someone else around to play splitscreen, you are pretty much limited to just singleplayer which just gets repetitive(even with the mods).\n\nIn short I recommend this game only when on sale for less than $5, as you can buy much more in depth games for the same price. And only if you have an affinity for games that mix strategy and action.
voteText: 6 of 10 people (60%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I love this game! Its like worms with soldiers in real-time plus some strategic elements. However its hold back by the lack of updates and performance issues when there is a lot of action. I heard that this game is awesome when playing with a friend (thus avoiding some AI issues). I haven't yet, so I talk about single-player only here!

Sadly campaign mode with AI enemy seems broken. AI is kinda hard in an unpleasent way. You should build a bunker but realy the best bet is to raid the enemy as soon as possible taking lucky shots at his commander. Also the enemy can do multi-tasking (build base and attack you) while the player can only do one thing at a time. Its sad but the campaign mechanics seems broken to me because of this (or better - the campaign mechanics do not play well with the games strengths). It is still fun, especially the missions, but I can't keep looking at the issues and the fact that the game seems abandoned by its developer.

Like said, I love this game but unless it is updated to address the issues I can not recommend it for the price of about 19$.

If anything, grab it on a sale and try to enjoy the better working missions - you'll either love or hate it.

reviewText:
This game is definitely unfinished... Urgent patching needed...

AI is brainless... Forcing you to control your troops one at a time... Enemy AI shoot well, but that's about it... Ressource Collectors get often lost, stuck or dead, forcing you to keep an eye on them...

Robots are spineless and take forever to walk, forcing you to use and abuse the jetpack, even if you often damage them with a rough landing...

Building base is ok, but you can't seem to put a brain in it, unless you keep the roof open, giving a wide area for the enemy to infiltrate it... Or you can put a Walking Brain deep in your base, an hope it won't do something stupid, like getting outside to fight the war itself...

reviewText:
Eleven years in the making and the game still isn't finished.
Don't get me wrong, it's -playable-. Fun, after a fashion. But it lacks focus.

The AI is infinately better than human players in the battlescape screen because it cheats*, and the human controls are badly implemented. It is far better to set the AI on your robots to attack, then step away from the controls, and occasionally buy new ones to throw into the grinder.

As a person to person multiplayer, it could be good, but it also loses a lot of the building elements, simply because human players are not going to stick around to micro-manage base building, so again, better to let he AI decide on base structure. Also, there is no online option. It plays only in split screen on controllers.

Last but not least, it also does not recognize victory conditions (All except one player eliminated). I bought this in a Humble Bundle while it was still in production. I do not feel ripped off, but would not buy in its current form.

*100 percent accuracy, knows where all resources are, is able to control multiple units at once.

reviewText:
having played 118.1 hours on this game I can safley say that this game is fun and entertaining and a perfect blend of combat, strategy, and construction

some of the things I like about this game
- degradable/destroyable terrain, construction, and rubble
- the factions all have unique weapons and units that make each one original and a different playthrough every faction
- the multiplayer helps entertain friends/guest, but it isn't the main focus of the game and the ai is compitent which makes playing alone just as fun as with others
- I like how if you aren't great at building bunkers, there is an auto build in campaign mode that takes your avalible reasorces an builds a base for you, and in skirmish (quick game) mode building isin't always the main focus
-lastly the game is nolonger extremly glitchy, in fact I have never encoutered a glitch in all my time playing
-the game is realistic in the sense that if you get shot to many times, without a med bot you will bleed out, instead of running away to a corner and wiping the strawberry jam off your face like in most war games

and so I would rate this game a solid 12/10

reviewText: I saw my enemies dropping from a done so I used a grenade launcher to knock out the left engine. It cirlced in the air and flew down into the soldiers, killing them. The parts flew and killed my solder. I came back and that wreck didn't disappear; it was part of the landscape. This game has 100% (100% is not an exaggeration. It is one hundred percent deformable) deformable landscape which means if you're standing above the room where your enemy's main brain is hiding, you can have a squad of your soldiers armed with shotguns shoot a hole through 5 foot thick concrete and wires and rebar where your squad will fall onto the brain-droid and 2 soldiers, killing them all. Your gun can be knocked out of your hand and even broken by gunfire while you're using it. Your legs can be shot off as your arm can be. I spent 30 solid seconds flying around, limbless, with my jetpack when I flew into an enemy and killed him with the impact. Dead bodies also become part of the landscape. I've taken cover behind 3 of my comrades more often than behind actual cover. The command mechanics are *extremely* unique and interesting, and the plethora of mods in 2 days is staggering. I'm sure you've exaggerated the greatness of a game, maybe even said that you couldn't possibly tell someone why the game is so good and they just have to see for themselves but... You really have to see for yourself. I believe it's still 10 bucks but 20 is more than fair. I bought Cortex Command with LEGO The Hobbit, which I'd been looking forward to since March and I've played about 45 minutes of The Hobbit in the past 2 days. Total playtime in those 2 days was 18 hours. Do the math.

reviewText:
VERY fun physics based game.

Pros:
-physics based action, including lots of explosions, shrapnel, and out-of-control robot torsoes.
-very well-developed factions with differing playstyles.
-mod support.
-did I mention explosions and shrapnel?
-the devs (despite their seeming disappearance) are still out there working on updates
-you can play either a campaign-type game, or any number of scenarios ranging from bunker attacks to sandboxy test ranges

Cons:
-the game has a slight unfinished feel, for example: the physics can be a bit weird(arguably part of the charm)
-mods are usually unbalanced

Examples of the Awesome:
You shoot the lone robot guard of the enemy's bunker with a RPG
date: destroying it and sending it's head flying at Mach 2...you advance on the bunker victorious. You're just inside the doorway of the bunker! YES! YOU DID IT! YE-NOOOOO! The supersonic head has just come back around
hoursPlayed: February 2, 2015

reviewText:
So first of all as te devs. say, the metacritic is complete b******t and don't pay any attencion to it, now on to the game,

Its down right awesome, there is a mulitude of veriety in this game, the game is just about 2D shooting but also basebuilding, tactics , simple grandstragety and much more. although I didn't spend much with the vanilla units, the're all unique in their own right yet all well balanced, however where the game really comes to life is the modding community which in by far one of the best I've ever seen in any singular game this is also helped by how easy the mods fit into the game, almost as if C.C. (cortex command) was built around mods, and it works, as for the gameplay which can dip in quality especily with the squad commands, as the A.I. can be really stupid in situations such as when you lead a formed squad to the top of a mountian and the squadmembers would just jet up and down instead of droping to the ground.
although the ai can be a little stupid  here and there, this game is well worth the price of admission.

8.7/ 10

reviewText: Cortex Command, while holding a warm place in my heart, will probably never be finished. It has been years, and the engine sill lags and twitches, too many models in-world cause all models to explode, the controls are still a clunky mess (made for controllers
date: like that excuses awkwardness), the enemy AI's ability to perform multiple tasks (or even one task at speed) restricts you to either spamming skeletons or sticking to multiplayer, but the lack of online multiplayer or any sort of balance between factions and weapons makes the splitscreen multiplayer we're stuck with a bit of a crapshoot. And really, playing an already-cramped platformer RTS on a controller with half a screen is uncomfortable enough; I shudder to imagine it with four players.\n\nPeople will say you can just mod it into the game you want, but I shouldn't have to; if it's not the game I bought, and it's not the game promised to me, then why did I pay money for it? Why would you tell other people to pay money for it? People will say that I should lower my expectations because it isn't finished yet, but the developers have given the all clear on features that are nearly unsalvagable, like the campaign or your troops digging off the edge of the map. While they finally added squad mechanics, that doesn't fix a broken and unchangable control scheme or the fact that you can't leave your own troops alone without them killing themselves. And I think the worst part is, for all its flaws I can't think of any other game that tries to be what Cortex Command set out to be, what it promised to be, and as such can't suggest a better alternative. Again, it's just a darn shame.

reviewText:
I've been around since 2008, saw it grow and all. Not exactly worth the money in its current state, honestly.
Here are the pros and cons. The rest is up to you, dear reader.

Pros:
Physics, destruction of virtually anything pixel by pixel
Extremely moddable (+now you don't even need the Datarealms' forums and the good old manual installation, lots of stuff is getting ported to the Workshop)
Great spritework
Lots of fun in a metagame-based campaign, albeit an unfinished one

Cons:
Unfinished
Was an early-access ripoff before it was cool and everyone was doing it
Only local MP, no online play (splitscreen is still fun, but real MP is actually completely possible, as once proven by the awesome modders of Datarealms)
Bugs, no mods/tweaks that fix them
In development hell still (+complete with Data switching to other crap)

reviewText:
Never before have I wanted to give a middle-thumbs for a game as much as I do now. Cortex Command is an incredibly depressing game. It's a beautiful brainchild of a passionate person or people who just did not want to polish their ideas. They game has been in development about eight years now, and it's still in a miserable state. It's horribly bug ridden, there are amazingly careless and obvious mistakes and errors, there's huge balance issues and very little depth, and it's stagnated for a ridiculous amount of time. This game is going nowhere. It's a perpetual prototype, seemingly never to be fixed or improved. A prototype with game-breaking bugs, including the overworld map not fitting on the screen, or fullscreen causing immense lag, or you just getting stuck in a wall all the time. Not to mention the game has prolonged lagging episodes constantly.

But what a fun prototype it can be. The game is at times incredibly tense as you try to find an opening to shoot while desperately trying to avoid having any bit of you out in the open, and the game is at times hilarious as drop pods go astray and crash into a squad of troops. It is perfectly viable to win by dropping a crate of crabs on the enemy brain's head. They game is incredibly silly, but also extremely engaging. It takes a lot of effort to take down some of the enemies, and it feels very rewarding when you manage to do so. The base game has incredibly potential.

Let's talk about the actual game for a second. It's a 2D shooter with strategy elements. It's very hard to compare, there's really nothing like it. You have your typical base building aspects; you want a unit or two mining for gold, yet you also want a few armed units hanging around defending your brain/HQ. Most of the time you're be controlling a single offensive unit of some sort, kitted out to your liking. You have to make sure your brain lives, and the enemy's brain dies.

It's set in multiple scenarios. There are a few separate missions, including a horde/defense mode and a few assualt based modes. There's also a campaign mode, where you will capture points and build bases on them, then try to take over the opponent's bases. Although, that mode suffers from the previously mentioned glitch concerning the overworld map, making it so you cannot see and select some of the base building points, making it impossible to win. And that's it. You got about five missions and a frankly boring and repetitive campaign mode and that's it. There are a few nice mods that add some, but it's just a bit more icing atop an inch-tall cake. You ought experience everything the base game in about four hours, you can add probably add another four to six with mods. It depends how much you can stomach before getting bored.

The game has a very robust physics engine which allows you to contort into all sorts of hilarious positions, but it is also incredibly clunky. The menues are a mess, the characters are extremely slow, and you will accidentally kill yourself in hysterical yet infuriating ways. This is a good and bad thing. At first it's novel and interesting, then it's incredibly frustrating. Then it's a bit easier, then it grows fairly boring. There is a huge arsenal of weapons, but a lot of them feel the same, and a lot of them are somewhat disinteresting. Again, the base game is there, and it's great, but there is absolutely no filling, and there is bare minimum content. Your enjoyment of the game will depend entirely on how much you can put up with repitition and how far the bare basics of the gameplay can carry you.

In the end, I cannot recommend Cortex Command at the asking price of twenty dollars. That's simply too expensive for so little content and polish. It's also a game that I don't entirely feel comfortable supporting, as it's eight years in development yet still contains crippling bugs. It really feels like the developers just didn't want to bother polishing their initial ideas, they didn't want to do the boring parts. It's like an unedited paper, they just wanted to jolt down all their interesting thoughts and conclusions but they didn't want to spend time making it presentable to an audience. Such a shame.

On sale, you might want to consider it. It's got a few laughs and fun moments between the frustration of the brief experience, and it has a lot of toys for the more imaginative players. If you like weird 2D shooters with comically spasmic physics engines with some resource management, wait for a fifty percent sale bringing it down to ten dollars. If you're not interested in that or you can't stand major bugs or you need significant motivation besides gameplay, avoid it like the plague. Also, don't bet on this game ever being finished, or even improving significantly. Eight years of dead air does not bode well.

Honestly though, this game is sheer fun. 10/10 I love this.

reviewText:
This game is one of my favorite games. There are some problems with it, but the sheer amount of fun that you can get in return far outweighs them. I probably have put in 700-800 hours in this game before it came on steam.

Pros:
Active modding community
Fun physics
Easy to get the hang of
Fun meta-game
Many game modes
Workshop Support

Cons:
The is not much stock content in terms of missions and factions
Downloading mods is basically a given (Workshop makes that easy)
Slow to updating

reviewText:
This game is cute, but it is incomplete and only worth 4.99$.

Do not buy this game at its full price like I did. The content is so small and it's basically just one battlefield.

If this game were to get more work done on it, it might be worth more money, but considering they advertise as 11 years in the making, it seems like this is a same game that was made in 2001 and was ported to Steam in its incomplete state.

A few menus also give you placeholder text for certain menus that says the developer was too lazy to write a description here" for a few windows. A warning in the campaign menu says the campaign mode is not yet complete (this is after 11 years).

So yeah
date: 4.99$ game. That is all it's worth."

reviewText:
I played a lot of Cortex Command back in the day, but I always assumed it would eventually become more of a game. The 'metagame' is pretty strange and unpolished and I can't help but feel the developer just wanted to get it done so he can move on to something else.

Still, the game has some pretty amazing physics, where every pixel on the screen feels physically reactive. Filling a spaceship with crabs and crashing it into the enemy base is crazy and fun. The art is very well done and looks great on high resolution displays.

Would recommend for people who want a fun split-screen game, but not for the average person looking for a singleplayer campaign.

I wanted to love this game. But I can't.

reviewText:
Plays game with friend.

Starts having fun.

game crashes.

Best game I ever played.

==

If your use to garry's mod lag when it comes too much crap on screen at once, then you can understand the lag in this.

ALTHOUGH! the lag also may of been because I played this on a 6 year old computer with a Navida GTX 260 graphics card but I'm not completely sure, this also may of been the reason why it would crash sometimes.

The specs say it should work on any 5 year old computer but I geuss one more year was just too big of a leap for it, possiblly.

I just got a new computer so I'm gonna download it again 'eventually'.

If I notice a differance I'll change my review.

==

There is no online co-op so don't go buying this for your friends thinkin' you can play with them.
I was kinda sad when I found that out but it's still a fun builder like strategy game.

It does however have local co-op which is nice and even though I don't do local co-op that much anymore I still think it should be something more commen in more games.

reviewText: Genuinely, this game is fantastic. the physics engine is weird enough that you can still be surprised sometimes but no longer buggy enough that its frustrating. with the improvement of the object limit, we're now able to have massive battles that can be genuinely harrowing at times. I have had moments where I've been winning a battle by a landslide and they send in troops that absolutely wreck me. I'd then push foreword and get pushed back again and again. the difficulty slider being seperate from the A.I. intelligence slider is also incredibly fun. You can set the enemies to be bullet sponges, sure, but you can also get them to be intelligent and capable of taking you down. the campaign mode is fun at the higher difficulties, but I do feel that some more content and game modes would be fun. All in all, the game is fantastic and I highly recommend it. 11/10 it has eaten my life.\n\nAlso, I recommend modding this game. Although do be sure to uninstall the mods you don't want and then check to make sure they're gone in the games files, as sometimes steam won't remove them properly and the game gets clogged at start up from tons of files you're not using.

reviewText: Cortex Command (as far as I know) is still in development and it does show. The game works but movement can be very wonky. Movement is also very slow which I feel should be updated in the future. With that being said, this game holds soooo much potential and it's worth keeping an eye on. It has one of the best intros I've seen in gaming. It's a sandbox/strategy/combat game. It's very unique in its appearance and gameplay. You basically have a disembodied brain and with that single brain you can jump between and control different mechanical bodies. You then use these bodies to protect your brain and mount an attack on the enemy. The game lacks refinement but it will be interesting to see where it goes from here.

reviewText:
Worth every penny...

Pros:
- New and unexplored gaming means that you won't have experienced anything like this before (if you have YOU'RE LYING TO YOURSELF!)
-Replayable as it is completely sandbox
-Couch co-op & multiplayer so you can rub victory in your friends' faces
-Editable files, if you feel something is too op/not op you can chagne that (look up a tutorial though, if there isn't one just ask and I'll make it)
-Moddable, like REALLY moddable.
-Runs well as long as you have more than 1.5ghz dual core (with that you can't do much though (not epic battles and such))
-Encourages planning and strategy
-Encourages shennanigans and good times
-Encourages laugh your ♥♥♥♥ off moments
-Easy to learn, difficult to find a non-modded exploit (unless you edit the pistol to be a laser gun of bullets (like, spewing out insane amounts)
-Crabs... so many crabs
-Moddable
-Did I mention mods?
-Oh yea! That reminds me, there are mods.

Cons:
-Crashes if too many mods
-Crashes if too much ♥♥♥♥ happens
-Couch co-op & multiplayer so you might get punched when you thrash your mates since you've played this for 300 hours... Just me? Oh... ok then.
-A bit pricy for the game alone since it doesn't contain that much (but mods and local multiplayer fix that)
-No online features, no multiplayer at all, there is a mod for that but it's very broken and never really worked.

If you are thinking about getting this game, get it. It's truly brilliant and a hell of a good time. I mentioned mods right? I think I did... Mods.

reviewText: A lot of people these days like to play those games with stellar next generation graphics, and that is completely fine, but games like Cortex Command, styled sort of like Terraria, is in my opinion much better than a lot of games. Although I can barely survive a few waves with my meager heavy marine and his compact assault rifle, I love to see the little soldiers fight and ragdoll all around when they get hit, or crush each other trying to get out of a pit. On top of that its actually in my opinion fun to lose here, so I'd buy this if I were you.

reviewText:
It's one of the most overlooked games on steam, delivers amazing 2D warfare set in the future, the goal is simple, kill all brains of your enemy, with your units controlled by said brain, by any means available.. Let me just tell you, the amount of ways in which you can kill your enemies? PLENTY, drop a soldier in a crate right on your enemies units, or rockets as they fly in, bombard your enemies with napalm, or other rockets dropped from the sky. Alternatively, just send your units in, and kill your enemies with brutal force. After you kill a brain in one of the areas, you take it over, and build a base, in which your brain will be stored, enemies will try to take over, and will use any means necessary to achieve victory. And that's just the tip, there is a lot more to it, and is best played with friends on a couch. THE BIGGEST FLAW is lack of online multiplayer, which is really sad, and I really see no reason to why that is.. :(

All in all I strongly recommend that you play it, and here is a video of couch play I did with my friends, a videos against AI are also available so check them out, they are real fun as well :)


https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tmY6ZrXNtsY

reviewText:
This game is a VERY FUN game that is NEVER the same! Fun  wonky destructible terrrain and troops! I love the modding community for this game and hopes it updates more often! ALSO PLEASE add in a way to delete all your mods so the game can load in quickly and a way to put all the mods back in. thanks!

The updates are either months or maybe a year apart, none to fear as for the Fresh mods keep it alive... Sorta!  Check out DataRealms' other game coming out April 15 2016 Planetoid Pioneers, the prequel to Cortex Command.

Controls are wonky but hey, it adds to the fun and randomness. Also you're are a BRAIN, IN A JAR/ROBOT, controling bodies via microchip signal. Don't blame it for not knowing how to walk but know how to break dance.

Matches are very different and chaotic. Needs above decent computer to run it great all the time. Mine gets about 5-20 FPS. 20 FPS when nothing is on the map. 5-10 when killing things on said map.

Otherwise Great game if it had updated more often. Mods keep it alive and Replayability is great.

reviewText:
I have been following this game for a long time, since before it was on steam.  The modding community is great and it adds so much to this game.  I love the 2d style and destructable enviornments, however I could not honestly reccomend this game.

The issue here is performance, on multiple rigs I have had issues with not only crashing to desktop, but crippling lag as soon as a game runs too long or things start to get interesting.   It's almost to a point where it is unplayble.  Unfortunately, it does not matter what type of rig you have,  because this game only utlizes 1 cpu core and limited GPU as far as i know.  Either way the lag always creeps up and ruins the experience.    I don't know if there is a fix for this because the engine it was built on is old.

I don't see how they can recommend playing this with 4 friends, when the lag crushes the experience with just two people.  There are some tweaks for this online, but nothing solid to get the game running at 60fps consistently even on modern pc's.

All in all it has so much potential but It cant be realized because of the dated engine and lack of optimization.

reviewText: Excellent concept ruined by bad programming. The game is very, very inefficient and lags a lot even on the fastest computers. The reason probably is the fact that the game does everything in a single thread on the CPU and does not use any modern capabilities of computers whatsoever. There are lots of bugs (some may have been fixed since I last played), here is no network multiplayer, the campaign has no story and is too easy due to poor AI, the controls are poor both on gamepads (poor aiming accuracy) and with keyboard and mouse (hard to navigate menus). Do not buy this game.

reviewText:
I waited for that game so long, was eager to play with all theses robots in this beautiful environement. I even bought it before it's official release. But once it finally came out...omg, what a disaster.

The controls are extremely clunky, i lose robots everytime due to bad robot handling

The UI is infuriatingly bad.
No map or notifications to tell you something is happening back in the base (at least, until it's too late...when you see the red screen indicating your main brain is taking damage, it's too late to do anything about it). So either you constantly jump from your base to your attack force (and pray your attack force isn't doing something stupid while you're not watching it), or you just rush ahead and pray no surprise happens back at the base.
The buy menu is full of problems. It takes half your screen, yet is almost unusable. So you will create presets builds to avoid using the menu itself. And then you will find out the presets are also full of problems (can't combine them together, order of items matter, etc...)

So the minute to minute gameplay is full of problems, but the overall strategic gameplay is even more broken. It's always very unclear what you're supposed to do. In scenarios, the game may tell you thing like load onto a ship to escape"..."how am I supposed to do that game ?" "no telling you
date: figure it out !".\nAnd the campaign is in an even worse

reviewText:
This game feels like a game you get for free with something else...and it indeed was in my case as it came in a bundle. I know my hour counter says i sometimes play it, but that is irrelevant as this review is to convince one not to buy it. You can play something you got for nearly free and still advise people to not buy it.

Where do i start? Well for starters DONT BELIEVE THE BUILD 30 TRAILER". back when the game did reach steam it was in fact advertised to its community as DONE and ever since little to no news about it was ever shared and now after a very long time. NOW they show some returned interest in a game and defend it by saying "We should have communicated properly". they had a long time to explain that point and just now they do it. Thats just unexcusible.

Onto the game itself...its a tech demo. nothing more
date: nothing less and it will NEVER be anything but that.\nThe tech is nice and everything
recommended: but there just isn't any depth. At most you may mess around in one of very few levels or the kinda chaotic "campaign" now and then with a few modpacks just for the sake of it. but it gets horribly repetetive nearly instantly... There just isn't anything of substance. there was the promise of a campaign with the game's setup (you are a brain on a quest to create a empire on a Free for all planet
hoursPlayed:
neato). but that got shoved aside for the so called campaign currently and only a few scenarios hinting at the original plans remain.

Multiplayer is a joke. there is in no way any networking capability and only if you have multiple controllers of any use...only then may you find some enjoyment IF you have the controllers and friends wanting to play...which is more often a big NO.

Also the dev shrugged off bugs and "unpolished" features on the pretense of early-access. Thing is that most of these bugs have been there for YEARS.

In overall this game is something that began with potential and ambition
voteText: but now is horribly dated and the dev doesn't seem to put in any effort anymore. I say that unless the game costs a few dollar and you are willing

reviewText:
Anyone who has ever, truly cared about the RTS genre should want to play this game because it has every thing going for it. If you loved Steel Soldiers, you'll adore this.

The original story line and concepts are amazing, the units varied and creative, the guns are very unique and every unit has a jetpack.

The units in particular have sometimes amazing AI (units in squad will go prone if they are in contact and the unit behind them is shooting, stop friendly fire with HE) to not so good (jumping in to a cavern with a squad sometimes ends with an AI unit jetpacking in to a wall and staying there).

want to position a sniper or rocketeer on a nice big spot height? Jet pack! In trouble and need CAS? Dropship loaded with bombs or rocket full of bombs as a huge missile!

Every time you play, you find yourself wondering where the hell this game has been hiding and why no one came up with it earlier and where there are other devs with ideas this original and colourful.

reviewText: Terrible, just terrible. At first glance this game seems to have a ton of potential. You have a lot of weapons to choose from, alot of equipment and a lot of gear to arm your robot avatars with, and the particle and physics effects are very neat to see. Unfortunately it only takes about an hour of play to exhaust all the fun you could have with this game. Every thing becomes to repetative. Small skirmeshes that range from to easy to almost impossible if you miss manage what little resources you have, and an overall unfocused set of game types thrown in almost as an afterthought. The multiple weapon types offer a bit of strategy to an otherwise mindless game, but once you become adept with some of the more exotic guns the game has to offer, you can abandon any strategy the game has in favor of brute strength.\n\nPlaying against a human oppenent makes things far more interesting, but having only local multiplayer in this type of game seems like a rather silly design choice by the developer. If this game really took a decade to make, perhaps another year on the design table would have done this game wonders.

reviewText: A great concept poorly done. The big issue is that it is a buggy mess a lot of the time. Poorly optimized which is very apparent when you have large numbers of actors in the scene or when multiple/numerous explosions occur OR after playing for long enough (without crashing) and the remains of actors and weapons cover the field. All of these can cause massive frame drops and/or the game crashing. AI is rough and glitchs can randomly cause your brain to die causing instant failure of the mission. Without mods the game suffers from a lack of content with various missions being similar if not identical to others in how they should be played and campaigns suffer from excessive repetition. To get the most enjoyment you really need some imagination or community mods which are in ample supply. Enviorments and actors are nicely made. Decent selection of weapons in vanilla version alone. Gameplay is enjoyable even with the bugs, however frustration can easily ruin your experience. The developer's dedication to this game is also very questionable and even with the recent update I have still suffered these issues. Even when on sale for half off I still regret my purchase.

reviewText:
Cortex Command by Data Realms is a 2D combat and physics sandbox, featuring a vast array of weapons, bodies, rockets and so on. There is no real objective, most of the time you are trying out different weapons and mess around with the game's physics.

It's not a bad game at all.  For a while it's fun to fly around with your jetpacks, shoot stuff, and try things from the workshop, but at the end it's not much more than the rather unsatisfying slashing of the dumb enemy horde-AI.

If you are looking for a combat sandbox, try the Men of War series in singleplayer, where you can command EVERY unit with WASD (like in Cortex Command), but actually need a strategy (unlike in Cortex Command). If you are looking for a 2D combat sandbox, try King Arthur's Gold (Multiplayer). I occasionally come back to Cortex Command to blow up some bodies, but only when I am (mentally) too exhausted to play games with higher demands in reaction and concentration

It's not bad at all, and some will certainly have fun with the game, but there is just no reason to play it unless you are extremely bored  and have too much money.

reviewText:
This game is really hard to explain. It's a 2d side scrolling game where you build a bunker, put your brain as your head honcho inside, and call down a truckload of soldiers to protect it. Or you can try some of the other gamemode's, like the one where you call down soldiers to attack an already existing bunker and win by war of attrition.

The physics and way people practically shatter after they die makes for some funny scenarios. Like the time when i killed a bunch of people just standing around, and put my guy atop the mountain of dead bodies as he ripped through reinforcements.

The controls are awful (so is this review), but you get used to it after 3 hours really.

also crabs skeletons and chainsaw rocket launchers ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°)

reviewText: There are two things that really makes Cortex Command shine: The physics, which applies to anything that is active, and even to terrain to a certain degree, and the near-absolute modding freedom. Everything except the very core of the game can be modified, and you can also create your own content. Even the core is starting to get exposed with the new Lua compatibility! These mods can be anything from a simple pistol to a hypercharged giant walker with a cannon that can blast half the level away and so on. With your wobbly legged brain-robot you must destroy the enemies brain or on other modes... Faceplant into the ground, blow yourself up, snipe someone without legs, and ALOT more craziness. This game is one of my all-time favorites and will always be.

reviewText:
I've followed Cortex Command since long before the day it was availible on Steam. I've always been fascinated in the intricate physics system, and how literally every single pixel has it's own properties outside of being purely visual.

I feel like this isn't as appreciated as it should be, but really, the fact that Cortex Command has split screen local multiplayer is SO GREAT. Just as the intro screen says, just grab some buddies and controllers, and you've got yourself a mighty fine party game.

While there are bits about it that are ridiculously unstable, there's always so much going on in any game that I can't help but to laugh whenever characters randomly explode into bits for absolutely no reason. With the modability of the game and the integration with Steam Workshop, there are some seriously fun gamemodes and  additions out there to work with to keep the game fresh, action packed, and at times... just... really weird.

10 spontaneously combusting Coalition soldiers out of 10.

reviewText: I love this game. Never before have I played a game where you can design a bunker, set up turrets inside, and call down troops from dropship, each soldier chosen and customely outfitted by YOU. The entire game is physics based. The walking, flying, climbing, and crawling, is done with your own characters 2 hands and 2 feet. Also, the plethora of mods, secenarios, and minigames make this game fun as hell even if you exhausted the vanilla game. Most of the major problems this game had before (Stupid AIs couldn't follow through with orders, Glitches, and movement errors) have been fixed. The new squad system has made the AI competent at organizing troops. You can create a squad to attack the enemy base, and turn around and focus protecting your own.  Just bringing down soldiers is awesome. Nothing is as beautiful as several dropships floating down from the sky, with AA missiles rising up to meet them. The game is just so versatile. Need to clear an enemy bunker? Send in masses of cheap robots, clones, or zombies, or send in a heavily armed squad of tough elite units, or fricking have crash test dummies go the long way around dig through the walls to eliminate their defenseless commander.\n\nThis game is special. It's mechanics are something I have never seen before, and don't think I'll see again for a along time.

reviewText:
Back in my young college days there was a downloaded version of this game going around amongst my friends (I really wanted to buy it but couldn't spare even the small amount of money required). At the time it was an unfinished sandbox where you basically downloaded mods and shoot crazy guns and stuff at terrible AI that practically just stood there.

Now there's actually a game here. The campaign consists of taking and defending territories while competing with up to 3 othere AI players. You pick a place and if anyone challenges you for it you fight for it. Once you take it you can either design your own base within it, or pick a budget and let the game build one for you.

I found designing things to be a little unfriendly because i wasn't sure what everything was, and it can take a lot of time depending on how crazy you want to get. Considering that at the moment the campaign doesn't usually last a long time depending on how good you are and the settings you choose I didn't feel compelled to do it. Additionally you'll be taking over several bases over the course of the game and it would be insane to manually build each one unless you were really quick. However, the autobuilding feature of the game tends to build some pretty decent looking bases. The problem is that each day you give the computer a budget for your base and then it decides how to spend the money and in what order. This means over time the base will get better but at the beginning you might have a pretty incomplete base. When you get attacked and you have an incomplete base, it can be nearly impossible to protect.

The actual battles are where the game shines. You start with a brainbot or if you have a base he might just be a brain in a jar. He's basically your commander and if his fragile brain jar gets destroyed then its game over. I usually send him down to dig for gold while i let my other units guard him.

This game is a physics based game where each pixel acually has its own properties. Units are actually made up of connected parts that move and interact based on their physics. This means that every part of a character can be blown off and every spec of dirt or other material has its own properties that can be deformed. Bullets go through softer objects and ricochet off harder ones. Rockets all have their own forces and when they explode they shred into pieces that can effect characters around the environment.

This game is run by gold and every unit is bought and dropped into your scene through the buy menu that will let you customize the unit and what it's carrying. generally they all have jetpacks, and weight matters so you dont want to bog a guy down too much otherwise he'll get stuck a lot and won't be able to jetpack too high.

Once a unit is called down you can take control of him and use his arsenal to take out other units and hopefully their brain. This is the part thats both amazingly fun, hilarious, and sometimes frustrating. The AI has gotten pretty smart at navigating around the levels and everyone is so fragile it can get pretty difficult, but in a good way. Especially when you're outnumbered and units are getting close to your brain. Having to fend off guys while simultaneously trying to buy and call down more units can be really tense. Especially because you're always working within a changing budget. Juggling shooting things, buying things, and budgetting can be pretty crazy at times.

But the real craziness comes from the Cortex Command moments you'll experience. Blowing up dropships and having them rollover and land on top of the guys they just dropped off, then exploding is always awesome. Jetpacking out of control and then smashing into 3 enemy NPCs and watching everyone explode is hilarious. Sniping a guy from long range and watching his parts just fly off is super satifying, and if you get your hands on a rocket launcher, you're in for some serious entertainment. These moments almost never get old, and will keep you playing this game for hours on end. Even when you totally fail the simplest task and all these things happen to you, its still hilarious.

And when you get bored? There are a bunch of great secenarios and community made mods on the steam workshop that will keep the game fresh. weegee's unmapped lands 2 mod is a really great conversion of the campaign and probably more fun than the vanilla game itself. He even has his own interpretation of FTL in the CC world that's worth checking out.

I'll be honest, this game has a bit of a learning curve. In the current state I'm reviewing this game it's unfinished. The developer has admitted that all the features are in the game, they just arent polished, and thats true. There is a tutorial that does an okay job of teaching you the basics of combat and mining gold, but as far as the campaign part of the game goes, there's basically no guidance at all. The community has made up for this though.

In it's current state it's a game you can sit down and play for 15mins or 5 hours. However, you can really see the potential of the game, and it can really only get better from here on out. It's a great game to add to your collection, play until your burnt out, forget about it for a year or two, and then play it until your burnt out again. It's that solid and that evergreen. You'll never get tired of blowing things up.

Like the developer says in the video on the Store page. This game reviewed several years ago by alot of major sites in was was obviously an unfinished state. I'm not sure of the specific circumstances behind that, but this isnt the same game it was then. I'd argue it wasn't even a game then. Now it is, but still unfinished.

The message here is, don't believe the major reviews or metacritic score. Read the reviews on steam. Everyone is recommending it, just like myself.

reviewText:
There are not any games like this out there that I can find. This is a true original idea. I am VERY impressed.

I have been playing this game for a little while now. I watched a few videos on youtube to learn some of the gameplay and also because this game is so fun to watch.

When I started playing myself I was really impressed with some of the technology used in this game. I program games myself and some of the things these guys are doing are very impressive. The fact that all terrain is destructible and that the ai can actually find its way around in underground dugup tunnels is awesome! That path finding is impressive!

Heres my ratings:
Game play: 5/5 (very fun)
Music and sounds: (5/5 well done)
Graphics: 4/5 (they are 2D but literally 3D would make this not as good)
Multiplayer: 3/5 (From what I can tell it is only local multiplayer)


Cons:
-If there's one thing that can make this better it would be Multplayer not restricted to local. Figure it out guys.
-Get some procedural generation code in there for the maps. Right now you tend to play on the same maps. It can get old after many hours of single player.

If you add those two things to this game it would be worth 30 bucks and would be my new favorite game.

Great job guys.
