reviewText: Despite the tiny amount of time listed in Steam that I have played, I bought this game eight years ago and for around six or so of those years it was the most common game I played. It have watched its development (successes and blunders) all along, and the newest update adding in Workshop support is an amazingly great thing. The 2D sprites with physics on each individual bit of pixel and sprite debris, the fully destructible environment, the jumping control between bodies, the building bunkers and fortifications to hold back the onslaught, or the calling in wave after wave of reinforcements to raid and destroy the AI's brain are all great fun by themselves. What really made Cortex Command great was the prolific modding community on the games website, and now that Cortex Command finally has Steam Workshop integration it will be far easier for the masses to see the best of the work of the great modders.

reviewText:
First I would just like to say- Ive boured dozens, if not hundreds, of hours into this, but only just got the steam version. If you like the idea of this game, I would highly advise it, no matter what the other reveiws say, as personally I've found the bugs that do pop up to be forgettable ,and the core gamepaly to be fantastic.
PROS
-First of my favourite part of this game- local coop- This gmae allows up to four human palyers, with xbox controllers, in nearly ever mission, and can also have a A.I team in there. The primary reason I got this game, and kept it, was for this features flawless implementation.
-Huge selection of items- During the game, at any stage you can order a selected type of dropship to deploy units, tools or airstrikes. There are several factions, dozens of varied actors, and probably hundreds of bombs, guns and tools. Also, at the begining of some missions, you have acsess to the entire libary of content to build a customized bunker, that can stretch the entire map. The actors can be customized with every weapon of the game, but overloading them will slow them down, so you have to find the right balance. If the current selection of items is still to small for you, then there is the
-Mods- You can fight space nazis with space marines. Enough said.
-Gamplay- I'm not denying this game has some issues that need fixed, but this game palys flawlessly in most cases. some movment looks unnatural sure, but at the end of the day, this  gmae is a working mix of world map campaign, squad based , terraria like mining, base building,destuctible enviroment multiplayer shooter. AS much as I love it,, these features also make it a potential
CON(S)
-Complexity- AS some of my friends who are used to simple shooters like COD said, thsi game is a little complex. Although I think the dozens of diffrent gamepaly elements are as streamlinned as possible, the game still takes a bit of gettign used to. Which brigns me to the second con..
-learning curve- Im going to be honest, the tutorial is a bit lacking in its current state, qit hzero info on how to use the campaign menu. However, after lookign up some internet guides, the games secrets reveal themselves quickly.
-Clipping issues- As a game with fully destructible enviroments, actors trying to get out of the palyer build catacombs some times get indefinatly stuck on on peices of terrain, but this can be fixed with a quick zap of a digger.
Overall, this game is deffeinatly worth getting, esscpecialy since the developer has stated that they have not left this game.

reviewText:
This is a unique game. I can't reccomend it for everyone, because it is hard to jump into, and has it's flaws. when you do get into it, though, it is very rewarding.
essentially an RTS sidescrolling sandbox of pixelated carnage, Cortex Command shines when the first enemy dropships start to land. mowing down troops can be a challenge, and while shooting the engine off a dropship causes some problems for the troops inside of below it, it easily may spiral off and crush your costly rocketeer as well. and the body of that rocketeer, crushed under the rubble of a spaceship? it stays there, to be chipped away at by bullets, explosions, and other bodies and pieces of debris crashing into it.
that's the best thing about the physics, I feel: every broken door and craft, each gunned down trooper, everything--will remain there until you trudge over it, shoot through it, or blow the area up. and explosions? they all have forces, shrapnel, and even fire flying out of them. a well thrown grenade will headshot one soldier with frag and toss another off a cliff, possibly missing a limb.

this all sounds great, but the downfall of the game is trying to get into it. a slow load time, small text and occaisional lag and glitches, it isn't perfect. but as someone who has gotten the hang of it, I highly reccomend you try, as the metacritic score is an understatement if you ask me.

did I mention mod factions? oh, you'll find them for yourself...
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I know this game has gotten bad press, and that everyone thinks its rubbish...
But wait a second... this game has a BRILLIANT gameplay, with scenarios and techs (factions) that will keep you coming back for more. Sure, 'data realms' has all but abandoned this game in favour of some dunebuggy alpha test,
but the modders can, and WILL keep this game alive...
And i am currently creating a faction myself... but due to its size, don't expect it to be complete outside next year at best...
Remember though, that the only reason this game has survived this long (11 years! more than most COD games!) as an active game (in a sense) is because of its great engine and its easy acess to modders...
yes there are rubbish mods, but Skyrim (a UTTER favourite of mine) has MANY MORE OF THE SAME SH***YNESS!
This game will live on... the real question is when Data realms asks the modders to complete his game for him!

reviewText:
I've been playing Cortex Command since its earliest builds many years ago. I've watched the game evolve and take form and improve every feature. The first mod I've ever made for a video game, years ago, was for this game.

Yes it is a strange game and can feel sluggish or imprecise, but it is part of what makes the game so much fun to me. The environment can be as much of a threat as your enemies as each footstep digs slightly into the ground and every action terraforms the battlefield.

There is plenty of fun to be had in this game an I could not reccomend it enough. It has been one of my most favorite games since the day I bought it and still to this day, years later, It is one of those games I could never uninstall because I just never know the next time I want to boot it up for a quick mission, or to start a new full campaign.
Killing is extremely satisfying. Dieing makes you really feel it, but is almost always hilarious.

There just isn't enough I can say about this game other than if you have any interest in it at all. Buy it and support the developers because they really deserve it. They are some of the most dedicated and oldest indie developers around.

reviewText:
Postives:
-If you like sandboxes, this is your game. You can mold the enviroment using drills, bombs, bullets, or driving a rocket full of crabs into the enemy base.
-The amount of mods that are availible for this game is kind of suprising, these can add many hours of content onto the base game. Steam workshop has been integrated with this game making mods much easier to access.
-The game is easy to load up and play, and never really gets old.
-The retro graphics are good, and are great when put with the engine.
-Its all about player-defined choices, there is no pre-set strategies for you, you get to make your own. Personally this makes it very entertaining.
-The game can run on older machines with a somewhat fast processor.
+++++ Recently the Devs decided to pick up the game again! That means more updates :)!

Negatives:
-There is a problem with a lack of content, with mods this can be fixed, but the game itself is relatively small.
-Paying 20$ for this game seems pretty spendy for game that is not fully complete".
-Some of the factions are quite OP
date:
it would be nice if they were balanced a little better.
-The game is not very user-friendly and does take a learning curve to understand it.
-The AI can be stupid and clunky and points.


The Verdict:
Buy this game

reviewText:
The bread and butter in this game is in its sandbox mode.Campaign mode is stil quite buggy and is being worked on but should be quite nice when its as good as you can get.

In campaign you send machines or humans to dig and collect gold to fund your warring.The Enemy A.I also needs to do this so you will be fighting for control of the various areas.Once one of you wins you get the area and it becomes a attack/defend thing.You get these brains that server as the nerve center of your operations.You have to keep them safe because if they get killed you lose the map.You get a certain number of brains that you can use but once their all gone, the campaign is lost. The brains you get are also what you have to defend n sandbox mode.

In sandbox you build a base,dig for gold (your drones you give orders to do it) or you can urself,and defend yourself. Anything a enemy is carrying you can pick up and use for yourself. Your soldiers legs get blown off? As long as he not dead he can move around. Robots can be reparied, humans can be healed but their limbs once gone are gone for good.

The games A.I. is quite well though needs some work here and there,but there are mods (and I mean tons of mods) many of which can make the A.I. a tough cookie,add new units,armor,weapons,etc.

I dunno if I can recommend it at $20,but I can say its good for at least $10 min $5.

reviewText:
TL;DR: Great game with a few glaring problems.

This game takes the best parts of worms armageddon and Soldat, and then mashes them together in a genuinely enjoyable, frantic RTS.

It's not really (at all) balanced, but to me personally that's alright because you'll be playing everything offline anyways.

The local multiplayer is CRAZY fun, and there's hardly another game with couch co-op this good.

BIG ASTERISK:

Programming wise, this game has LOTS of problems. Frame rate drops, crashes, glitches, and more! This can be incredibly frustrating when you've been playing a game a few hours and lose all your progress.



Definitely worth picking up, despite its numerous flaws.

reviewText:
Personally I can't understand the negative critics. Yeah, it is wonky at times but that's what makes this game so great. There's just so much stuff that can happen out of nowhere. For example when you order new equipment but all of a sudden an engine from the spaceship that's supposed to deliver your goods blows up, the whole thing starts spinning out of control and rolls over a bunch of attacking enemies. Love it.

Also there are dozens of game modes and also almost infinite playing styles. No matter how you want to reach your goal, you can do it, thanks to completely destructible terrain. And this is what makes the game so great, the destruction is just epic. Plus characters and vehicles are also fully destructible, piece by piece. Characters wear protective armor you can shoot off or try and aim for the fleshy head that explodes in a satisfying shower of blood. Vehicles also wear protective armor and if you aim well you can blow engines off of them so they spin out of control. That's the reason why I love this game. There's tons of details built into the satisfying destruction that this game offers.

Yeah, the performance is not the best when there's a lot going on on your screen. But even before the Steam version I have been playing Cortex Command for hours upon hours upon hours with friends and we had loads of fun with it. Definitely recommended!
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Cortex Command is a game where you build a bunker to protect your brain, place your brain inside of said bunker, and then place different types of guards around the bunker so that enemies have a hard time getting in. You then start the game and enemy ships start landing on the planet.

Then ♥♥♥♥ gets crazy yo.

You are waiting for one of your dropships to bring in more troops since the last lot are currently blocking up the entrance to your base with their dead bodies when suddenly you hear an explosion, so you quickly zoom around the map looking for the source of the sound, and you see that one of your (barely functioning by this point) turrets has destroyed one of the engines of a dropship. You then watch as the dropship spirals out of control, smashes into the ground (and your turret) and explodes. What cargo was that dropship carrying? That's right. Mother♥♥♥♥ing mine bombs. Mines go everywhere. You then realize that your dropship has arrived. but it's too late, and everything explodes in an awesome tornado of dropship bits and body parts.

There's also local splitscreen multiplayer.

Why haven't you bought this game yet?
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Cortex Command-
A game where you can stuff 50 crabs into a small crate drop it in from orbit onto an enemy base and watch it slowly sink down into the ground and then explode sending crab insides crashing through the enemy base killing all within its reach.

I play this on a pretty crap laptop and yes it does lag pretty badly at times. But so what? I can literally spend hours on this game lag or no lag.

I see people complaining about strategy?
Ramp the diffiulty up to nuts the enemy A.I. up to unfair and give about 10,000 funds and now you're gonna need some strategy. I've spent ages simply designing and redesigning bases to find the best way to stop myself getting destroyed by the enemy.

The only downside I can find in this game is the lack of multiplayer. If it was implemented my hours in this game would probably be much much higher. But unfortunately as far as I can gather due to the way the engine is multiplayer seems impossible. But if it is the last thing that the devs ever did for this game I would be so happy.

So,
Cortex Command. If you want to give your enemy a box filled with crabs as a gift well this is your game.


Also-
The mods are amazing for this game. 90% of them are to be found on the forums not on the workshop so make sure you go there too if you're looking for some.

reviewText:
I really don't understand why this game gets bad rep. Maybe because it doesn't exactly have a fully-fleshed out campaign mode? Maybe because it was in development for a heck of a long time? I don't know. What I do know is it's a ton of fun.

It's a physics-heavy 2D shooter where stuff like hit detection is calculated by the PIXEL, and the physics really are the coolest part. You can blast enemies to beautiful bloody giblets with a multitude of weapons, drop bombs to destroy terrain (and soldiers) and when you're done bombing, accelerate your dropship to insane speeds and slam it into anything that's still moving, creating a deadly explosion of fire and shrapnel.

If I'm going to be perfectly honest, I have a few gripes with the game myself, but for how incredibly unique it is compared to every other shooter out there, and how fun it manages to be despite being so different, it deserves better than a 44 on metacritic.

reviewText:
This is a nice Indie game that could easily be overlooked. Everything about it screams retro side scroller, however I was pleasantly suprized to see alot of interesting gameplay mechanics. It's part castle defense, part RTS, part contra style shootem up. If any of these things sound appealing to you this may just be your game: building the most inpenitrable base, sending waves of units to take out an enemy base, or Running around blowing limbs of scores of baddies, Resourse management and development, or sitting back and letting the computer do it for you.

The game is based in a very distant future where people's brains controll robotic legions to fight over resources. Everything about the game can be found in its opening cutscene (which might i add is freaken awsome) The core gameplay revolves around you Brain... both literally and virturally represented. The brain is either a moving robot or a static part of your defense that controlls all other actors and units. Its pretty simple kill the Brain, win the game. Initially when you occupy a planet at the same time as an opponet your brain will be air assaulted in with a few minor units ( In most cases a mobile sentry with anti arcraft rocket) From there you can call in additional units expending a gold resource that can be mined. Once a plannet is in your controll you can put your gold into building your dream base or have the computer do it for you. In the campain you set the number of factions and faction types along with the number of brains they have. Once all the brains are gone you win... or loose. Lets move on to the actors/units you can rain firery death with.

There are a few tarting factions in the game ( which can be expanded with player made mods) Each faction has a pool of troops (actors) weapons, tools, and aircraft to choose from. In the campaing by selecting a certain faction gives you a discount towards thier troops and gear, however you are not constrained to just that faction type. When your brain calls up troops you'll have a window that you may select the troops and thier eqipment. You start of with how they get thier, what troop type, and eqipment thier carrying. The initial equipment and weapons is expansive, with every weapon and tool verying greatly between eachother. A unit can hold many weapons and tools and freely switch between them on the fly, however if you load up on to much you cant fly... This brings me to another point. All your units are equiped with jet packs. This is both awesome and fustrationg as menuvering your flyboys and girls cand take some practice; and will most likely end up with your trooper splattered against a wall or something. Its almost like Tribes meets Contra.

The combat in this game can be pretty intertaining. All troops have body parts that can be blown off with well aimed shots; can make them beguin to bleed out or not. Another option is shooting the weapons out of enemies hands. The RTS aspect lets you select a groop of actors and set them on a patroll, Guard, Brain hunt mode, or designated points. You can also form a squad and have them move together and/or follow you. This is a pretty interesting aspect and gives the game some depth and versitility. If you feel like being rambo you can,  want to dropp in with an expensive hit team into the heart of the enemy defenses you can, or if You just want to send wave after wave of troops while you mine for gold Terraria style to fund it YOU CAN!


This is a very enjoyable game and has many interesting elements not utilized by other games. It is however not without its faults. The AI can be less desirable at times, as in getting stuck or just flat out non responsive. The game has a tendency to crash when overloaded with actors in the campain feature. The campain is very easy even on hard difficulty and there are many ways of rigging your planet to be niegh impenitrable. It would be a great improvement if you could choose to drop a couple bombs on key locations before your very vulnerable brain drops from the heavens just to get shot down my spammed rocket infantry.

All in all this is a great indi game and well worth a few bucks just to experience an outside the box game. It didnt have the backing of a AAA design team, yet still happens to pack some oomph.

These cons can easily be fixed so if they do i will delete all of them and give a purely positive review on the game, because thats all there will be left to say.

reviewText:
One of the best strategy games I have ever played, if you would call this a strategy game. The unique idea and original story make this game interesting, but it isn't polished enough to be called a finished product.

Start with a moderate amount of funds and take over a mining site on the planet. The amount you invest in an expidition is the amount you will have to purchase troops, upgrades, weapons. A small amount is taken right at the start of the battle in order to cover the cost of the brain and remote body. If you play smart and use the terrain and your troops effectively you will win without spending much. Simply pouring funds and troops into a battle is sure to make you lose in the long run.

Overall the game runs fine. The graphics are almost dated, but they don't look bad. It almost seems like something from the late nineties. Most players will be challenged, but those who enjoy a unique kind of strategy will love it. Try to start a new campaign and learn some of the basics before you form an opinion. There are some bugs, but nothing game breaking. The devs are still working on this game and there's some great add-on content.

reviewText:
This is what I would qualify as a mixed review.
First of all, I understand fully that the game is being developed. That, and the very fun elements of the game that I have enjoyed have permitted me to enjoy what I got so far, and hope for more. The game is inventive and seems to be a great piece of work. The problems it has fall into three major categories.

1) Streamlining.
Its pretty self explanatory here, but when I'm trying to build bases or order soldiers / guns, it takes forever to navigate back and forth between the menus. You'll know how to get from place to place after one good attempt, but the actual act of manuevering is never easy.

2) Polish.
AI needs some work. The bots are at the same time both lethal to enemies and themselves. They're bad at following you,  but sometimes highly skilled at it. They can't hit anything for ♥♥♥♥, one half of the time, and they're Rambo the other half. Some refinement would be much appreciated.

3) Glitches and Freezing.
I played this game happily with both previous problems until I was no longer able to enjoy it because the game stopped working. It would freeze during loading for around 5 minutes, then load the menu, freeze for a few minutes loading a game, and then again during play. This is a problem for any game, especially ones that aren't finished, but it needs work.

Still, after all of this, you should buy this game. Its hilarious and wonky, and sometimes a little unweildy, but its a great game and its worth your time and hard earned cash.

reviewText:
I really don't understand why this game gets bad rep. Maybe because it doesn't exactly have a fully-fleshed out campaign mode? Maybe because it was in development for a heck of a long time? I don't know. What I do know is it's a ton of fun.

It's a physics-heavy 2D shooter where stuff like hit detection is calculated by the PIXEL, and the physics really are the coolest part. You can blast enemies to beautiful bloody giblets with a multitude of weapons, drop bombs to destroy terrain (and soldiers) and when you're done bombing, accelerate your dropship to insane speeds and slam it into anything that's still moving, creating a deadly explosion of fire and shrapnel.

If I'm going to be perfectly honest, I have a few gripes with the game myself, but for how incredibly unique it is compared to every other shooter out there, and how fun it manages to be despite being so different, it deserves better than a 44 on metacritic.

reviewText:
Cortex Command is a game I've been following for a few years now, even before it came to Steam. It's a gem, and I'll tell you why.

OVERVIEW:

Cortex command is a sidescrolling shooting/sandbox game about building bases and defeating your enemies with superior tactics, skill, and numbers. If you were to take Terraria and Team Fortress, mix in some Real-Time-Strategy and add heavy helping of Sci-Fi, you'd get this game.

You control units, (via telepathy from your leader Cortex,) from any faction you'd like, and outfit them with the best weapons and tools you can buy, all in an effort to either protect your leader brain, or destroy your enemies'. You can pilot air vehichles, build bases, give your units orders, or command them yourself. There are many different game modes, each of which are fun in their own right. The combat lets you express your tactical skill in any way you can imagine. Drop a crate full of bombs in an enemy's base, crash a rocket through the front door and lead your troops in for a charge, dig underneath their fortifications and attack from below, scale a gaurd tower with a grappling hook, the list goes on. But don't take my word for it, feel free to watch the gameplay videos.

PROS:

The pixel art is lovely, the controls are smooth, if a bit wonky at times, (though it is a physics-based game, what do you expect?) The combat is all about your skill and how many bodies you're willing to throw at your enemy, and how creative you're willing to get to slaughter your enemies. Base-building has you express your creative side, and, while it can be tedious at times, the possibilities are endless and rewarding.  The workshop mods come in at a steady pace, so you'll never be bereft of new content. Also, if you've got some artistic skill and a little programming knowlege, it's not hard to make your own.

CONS:

The controls, while smooth, aren't easy to get used to. It's a physics-based game, so your movements are sometimes a bit clunky and odd. The base building also takes a while, so if you're playing with a friend, be prepared to either let the base be built automatically, or be sure your friend gets a turn designing. The biggest problem I have with the game, however, is that it's LOCAL MULTIPLAYER ONLY. That means you have to have your friends at your house, otherwise you're pretty screwed. But this could change in the future, but that's up to the deveolopers.

CONCLUSION:

All in all, I love this game, it's right up my alley. If you like sidescrolling shooters or if you like building games like Terraria, this game is right for you.

reviewText:
Note: I've played well over 300 hours in this game offline and off-steam in the 5 years I've been playing.

I highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys fun games with a bit of strategy.

Serving suggestion: This game is best served with a 3 gigabyte helping of mods. These can be found on the workshop.


GAMEPLAY

You play on a 2D sideview map usually with your brain and the enemy's brain having to dig gold and purchase different 'actors' to be delivered from orbit for you to use to attempt to destroy the enemy brain.

The physics in this game are very detailed and very important to winning. However, it may also be the thing that turns some people off. It makes movement feel somewhat 'heavy' and can be frustrating to get the hang of. But once you figure it out you'll be flying (yes everyone gets a jet pack) the body of your recently de-limbed trooper into the face of the enemy, hopefully decapitating them with the force... or maybe knocking the gun out of their hand... or the enemy might just laugh and shoot your face off.

All in all this style is easy to understand and very fun to execute due to the large amount of actors and equipment you can choose from. However some things like the grappling gun and repeller gun are not very useful or practical in normal games.


STORY

Not much here. We're a bunch of space brains with unlimited armies at our backs that are ready and willing to blast each other for gold.


GRAPHICS

The graphical style is wonderfuly done pixel art that isn't to pixely and is pixely enough it doesn't look cheap. It has just the right amount of detail to fantasticaly render every body part and machine piece as they explode and pile up on the map.


CONCLUSION

This is definently THE funnest game I have ever played in my life. The entertainment value is endless due to the active modding community and making mods yourself isn't that hard. It certainly won't disappoint if you can get used to the controls.

reviewText:
A video of this review can be found here.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0tpkUFlHpzo

I’ve poured in almost 70 hours into Cortex Command with no end in sight.  This may perplex you as Cortex Command was released in 2012 with… mostly negative reception.  However, the developers did not give up this project and have justified the 20 dollar price tag.  I’m usually not one to become obsessed with complicated games, but this game that has consumed me and make hours pass by like minutes.


The story is a great backdrop for a sci-fi sandbox game, and set up the great motives for why you’re doing what you’re and that makes it good. When Earth ends, Cortex Command’s story begins.  Earth had become a viciously dark place, and the only choice the human race had was to leave.  From our evolution we cast aside our insignificant bodies as our brains alone, were capable to control multiple bodies in tandem.  This made it effortless to leave earth as we were literally just brains that could be transported easily.  When reaching the deep edges of space, we as a species learned that we were not alone as well as not important.  After some growing pains, we all adjusted to the alien life.  However, resources were depleting quickly and species started looking towards other systems which will hold the setpiece for a lawless, wild west type gold rush.

The artstyle of Cortex Command is similar to sidescrolling 2D indie games like Terraria, but it leans more on its physics engine to be pleasing on its technical side. The pixel art blossoms, and the physics are heavy and satisfying.  Robots have a similar weight to the B.U.D. in Grow Home, mechs look like controlling hulking metal, and mining in the completely destructable environments beholds an ambitious animation proposition that is executed perfectly.The music is a magically airy chiptune selection.  It sets the atmosphere perfectly, and is a great background to the hundreds of hours you will spend plowing through the wasteland.

Have you ever played StarCraft?  In a sense, Cortex Command is the same idea.  Two bases build themselves up as they slowly try to frame their offensive attack to take out the other player. Instead of controlling multiple units at once, you simultaneously control and give commands to singular units one after another with the flick of a button. You land on a planet and build your base to defend your brain, the juggling and resource management is satisfying and immensely rewarding as you choose whether to attack or defend.  You can allot credits to have more possibilities as you mine for gold and build up your weapons.  Planetary scuffles can either swelter to a grand strike after multiple hours or a swift contest mere seconds into the match.  Jetpacks allow verticality and become weildly after a few hours with it’s amusing physics build. Keep a FAQ in hand however, as the games tutorials can be complicated and enigmatic.

Cortex Command is a Sandbox RTS game crafted by the folks at Data Realms, which is available for 19.99$ on Steam and Data Realms website. I purely suggest that you wait for a Steam sale and order multiple copies to gift to friends, as it’s very pleasant when playing with others.   Data Realm did not give up on their vision, and I applaud them for slowly improving Cortex Command into the game it is today.  Cortex Command is a game, that’s great for those who are looking for that new addicting game that stretches your dollar for hours upon each cent.

reviewText: While this game has a really cool concept, it's buggy and poorly executed. Basically the idea is that you conrol multiple units in real time to protect your base and destroy your enemy. There is a good variety of units and the terrain is fully destructible but many of the basic mechanics like movement can be buggy and frustrating. Though I'll admit the music is quite good.\nIf I had any confidence that this game would be updated in the future to fix some of these problems I might change my rating, but as it is the updates are few and far between. If this games sounds like something you might like, pick it up on sale, it's certainly not worth $20.

reviewText: The units you can control are very clunky and the most agile of the bunch are still difficult to move with. The game is NOT worth 20$. The game has many options to build your base, one can potentially create a large labryninth of corridors and rooms with intricate turrets and defendable positions. This isn't a positive though, as the annoying mobility of the game renders complex bases too clumsy to traverse through. The controls are bad and the game does not take it into account. THere are about seven scenarios to play on, as the multiplayer function does not function. The economics of the game do not balance well with the game. One ALWAYS has enough money to just create the essential unit to win. You don't feel any difference between units or weapons (of course there are the obvious assualt rifles and shotguns, etc.). The game is really repetitive. In a few reviews of the game on Steam and on Youtube, there were mods in the workshop to fix all the above problems, however the only mods are extra factions, maps, or items. You can download all the mods you'd like, however, the vanilla game's loading times are already terrible, and are made significantly worse with mods.

reviewText:
What the hell did I buy? Is this game still in beta or something? Let's see. Here are some of the things that are just ♥♥♥♥ about this game.

The game crashes whenever I try to change screen resolution and I had to manually change it in the ini files. It has the most unintuitive UI I have ever used. I am constantly searching for information on how to play the game because the tutorial didn't go through much. Buttons seem to have their functionality missing, such as the remove object and save button in the build mode. The text is TINY. The game is also really laggy so perhaps it could do with some optimisation.

I really really want to like this game but what the hell? I could understand if this was a pre-release version but the game has been out for 4 years!

Don't buy this. It may well have been in the making for 11 years but this is some half baked ♥♥♥♥ by guys who know how to code but who have no idea what makes a good user experience.

reviewText:
Cortex command seems like a game with a lot of time, hard work, and great ideas put into it, but it falls apart faster than my framerate does around the zombie spawners.

The game feels drastically unfinished, despite being past the 1.0 release.
There are several bugs that make the game extremely difficult to play at times, and frustrating to work around simple things like setting options or even manuvering your characters.

I can't reccomend this game to the vast majority of steam users, but if you have patience, and want to mess around with what could be an extremely cool game, consider cortex command.

Just don't go into this thinking you are buying a finished product.

reviewText: Interesting game, but just cannot seem to get into it. Clever idea, but could stand to be much better.\n\nNevertheless, it does have merit (expecially with mods).  I doubt it will ever be one of my favorites, but I won't say I don't enjoy playing it from time to time.  Still, if I were asked to recommend the game I'd have to say to wait until it goes on sale for $5 or less and then give it a try.

I can't imagine how they think it's worth $20.

Having seen the response video from the devleopers on this game, I thought I should add a note to say that my review was based on the assumption that this was a complete game (predating greenlight).

I would suggest buyer beware at this stage, but assuming the devs stick with the game, this could turn in to something pretty awesome. I'll be keeping an eye on the development, but for now I still wouldn't recommend it as a buy, unless you're buying to support the development team.

reviewText:
Cortex Command is an odd ball of a game. I bought it when it was first released to the public, in its unfinished stage. I played the hell out of it, dumped so many mods in there that it took it 10 minutes to start and I had plenty of fun with it. Its a great time consumer and there is plenty to do, especially when it comes to testing out weapons and causing massive destruction.

However it is also a game with some problems - multiple maps have almost infinte enemies spawning (not the problem ;), but as there is not limit, the game will begin to lag. Of course killing them instantly fixes it - but it is a weakness.
Another and more fundamental flaw from my view point is that I am never entirely sure why I am playing it. It is great to see a shot hit as intended or bomb the living hell out of a base. But when it comes down to it, I don't really feel productive.
Yes, I did say productive, which is an strange choice of word, but I do feel productive when playing other games, it might not be the productivity in the form of work - but more in the sense that I am accomplishing something. This game is not that type of game. Its a game with a huge fun factor, lots of mods and play as you want. But if you a looking for more than a great way to waste time, then this game might not be for you (at least until an hour later when you want to smash some skeletons, stomp on crabs and blow up a spaceship so much that your computer chrashes).

reviewText: You need two things before you play this; mods, & a local friend to join you. If you've got both, this is the most fun you've had in a while. Any issues fall away the moment your skull is detonated from across town by Darth Vader packing a .50 Cal rifle, poised atop a pile of skulls, stopping you from suicide bombing his home base. By yourself-or, even worse, without mods- , it's startlingly average. The A.I.'s dumb, the controls can be damningly obtuse sometimes, & there are days you'll see the crash report more than the Main Menu. By all means get a friend and play this, but only at a discount, or hell, check all those Humble Bundles you bought eons ago, you might have a copy.

reviewText: Cortex Command is a strange beast.  It is, without a doubt, not quite finished, and unfortunately it's likely it never will be.  The single player campaign is functional, but sparse, and a quick look at the scenario menu makes it obvious a dozen ideas and features never saw the light of day.\n\nNonetheless, the game shows its worth in the multiplayer.  It has fully functional splitscreen--a rare treat for a PC game--and it's in the gleeful chaos of a multiplayer scenario with a friend or two that the game becomes truly fun.  I've spent countless hours with friends building ridiculous, convoluted bases, defending them against hordes of enemies and whooping and gasping at every particularly visceral headshot or burning dropship obliterating everything in its path.  The physics are modeled exquisitely, every pixel destructable and every thrust of an engine or recoil of a rifle having a visible impact on the characters and surroundings.  In the thick of a survival scenario with troops and bombs raining down all over your bunker, drones dragging themselves around on broken legs, craters being blasted in the turf by overloaded rockets crash landing, and missiles and bullets whizzing in every direction while you scream at player 2 Oh god there's like thirty guys on the left"
recommended: insane anarchy.\n\nThere are also a truly impressive number of mods available
hoursPlayed: so if you want to be Master Chief taking on an army of orcs with a tuba that shoots miniature suns
voteText: well
helpfulPercent: you can.  My recommendation is mod Cortex Command to the gills
votesHelpful: invite your buddies over
votesTotal: get really drunk and scream incoherently as your base explodes around you.  You'll have a blast."

reviewText:
Great Game!

It is completely different from what the trailer depicts ( I suggest watching a few let's Play!" videos) but the gem that is underneath is beautiful...and a little flawed.

The Game is a 2D RTS/Platformer/Action hybrid where you take the reigns of a disembodied brain whose goal is to become rich by claiming all of the gold mining sites on the planet's surface.

Now...let me tell you the campaign is kind of dull (or at least I found it to be) but the varied skirmishes more than make up for it.

The hilarity of combat is what makes this game shine

reviewText:
I was at a stalemate against three two other factions: The Brotherhood of Nod and The Combine Overwatch. Somehow Nod had been able to kill off the Imperium of Man relatively early, although a contributing factor to their defeat was their strange compulsion to defend the tactically useless desert where their heavy units simply fell into the sand and were unable to retaliate.

Playing as the United Aerospace Corporation I had the unique ability to deploy all troops and supplies to the field instantly through teleportation. This had worked in my favor until I found myself caught in between a firefight between Black Hand confessors and Combine Elites backed by several Hunters. The instant my forces were on the ground they were incinerated. My stubborness to admit defeat and simply wait for another opportunity to take the site got the best of me and my defenses were spread ridiculously thin. I had ended up taking the cliffsides but it was not even remotely worth the effort. I had an ample supply of brains to reclaim any territory that would be lost to the enemy, but no funds to supply them with backup and the ability to purchase new recruits. At the same time it was plain to see that with the Brotherhood of Nod sweeping across Combine territory and emerging victorious, they had no plans to halt their advance and give me time to save up the cash to produce an army powerful enough to turn the coming red tide. I had no choice but to perform an extremely stupid and desperate attack utilizing all the resources I had at that point against a single stronghold that Nod had dumped most of its cash in. If I could capture this territory I would kill off almost 50% of their units occupying the planet and also maybe gain the use of some Nod units as well.

It was not going well at first, but then I massed a large group of minigunners and rifleman together on a high ground overlooking their main fortress. It was crawling with infantry and surrounded by turrets, but due to the sheer number of rounds I was throwing at them everything above the surface was slowly obliterated by an advancing swarm of lead death.

Finally I was able to send in a modest amount of men armed with shotguns, chainguns and plasma rifles. I was slowly pushing their troops deeper and deeper into a retreat, forcing them to fall further back to the depths of their fortress, bottlenecking them. I had them. My initial strike force was getting weak, so I ordered them to continue onward without my direct interference. I produced another marine, this time armed with a BFG9000 and sent him in to finish the job. My men had managed to corner their brain at the very bottom of the base, but they were missing most of their legs and arms and couldn't land a shot. Their death would not be in vain. I fired the BFG directly at their brain and one second before it reached its target the game crashed.

War is hell.

reviewText: Cortex command is a 2d sidescrolling action shooter that is filled with lol,wtf moments and a large variety of stuff. You play as a brain controlling units to fuel a never ending war over a planet and its expanse amounts of gold. It is very fun to play as you buy actors and weapons from space to fight your enemies.  It can also be played with up to 4 other players with local multiplayer. Unfortunately there is no online  multiplayer. On the topic of problems the game has quite a few. Random times were your brain explodes can be frustrating as well can be crashes. There are a variety of other bugs but the game is now once again being worked on by its developers. other problems are the game dosent save campaigns and the AI seems quite unfinished. You'll tell a unit to go somewhere but they'll end up taking a diffrent route and getting themselves killed. Once again the game is still being worked on and these problems will hopefully be adressed. But when you play with friends and download a couple mods the game can be very fun. I do reccomend this game and give it a 10/10, it is undoubtubly my favorite game.

reviewText:
In the far future, humanity sets out into space.  No longer held back by their fleshy bodies, they transfer their brains into jars, and send out robot clones to fight for territory on newly discovered worlds.  You are one of those brains, and you arrive on a planet in order to harvest it for its plentiful gold.  But you are not the only one searching for riches here.  Welcome to Cortex Command, a side-scrolling real-time strategy game from Data Realms.  This was one of the first games to try the “Early Access” style of development, where the developers sell an unfinished game to the public and allow them to download any updates for free.  Notch has commented that Cortex Command’s strategy was an inspiration for Minecraft’s development, and everyone knows how well that turned out.  Now, Early Access is a major feature of Steam sales and started a huge shift in games development, where the users directly interact with the devs as they create the game.  Cortex Command started all that, so let’s see what came of it.

In each scenario of Cortex Command, you will build an underground bunker to house your delicate brain while simultaneously attacking your enemy to destroy his brain.  You will do this by ordering bodies, weapons, and tools from the store, which are then delivered by dropship from an orbiting space station.  Take control of the bodies to command them directly, or issue them orders to stand lookout, charge forward, or dig for gold to power your economy.  All this takes place in procedurally-generated 2D levels, which look quite gorgeous.  The environment is fully destructible, and the physics are quite complex for an indie project.  Limbs will go flying after a rocket explodes, leaving body parts on the ground intermixed with all the guns and equipment, for the rest of the game.  Flying shrapnel pieces can actually injure or kill your clones and robots.  Jetpacks are difficult to control but can fly your guys across the map in no time.  The controls are comfortable once you get used to them, and you will quickly become adept at managing your little army of expendable bodies.

That is the simple explanation of this game.  It goes so much deeper.  You can take control of the dropship and use its thrusters to kill enemies in a fiery blaze.  You can pick up enemies’ guns off the ground and use them yourself.  You can tunnel beneath the enemy base to get around their carefully constructed defenses.  The situations and strategies you can employ are almost endless.  The store is chock-full of different options, and it can be overwhelming when you try to figure out what combination of stuff to use.  And that’s part of the problem here.  There is a short tutorial that explains basic mechanics, but there is no real learning curve.  The game doesn’t give you a real chance to explore its options slowly.  You are given everything upfront, with no real direction on where to go.  And what’s more, if you do choose a loadout at random and receive a delivery of useless equipment, now you have no money.  You’ll have to restart the mission and try again.  Not the best learning experience.  There are a number of specialized scenarios, which challenge you to survive with just a single unit while a horde of enemies bears down on you, or to defend a large base against waves of well-armed enemies.  These are good fun, and serve as decent ways to test out different equipment, even if none of what is going on is explained to you.

The cartoony visuals are quite entertaining, as bodies will explode violently and parts go flying.  Each faction’s dudes and weapons behave quite differently, but are relatively easy to tell apart once you learn who they are.  Exploring enemy bases and fighting your way through the unknown is a treat.  Every weapon has unique physics and sound effects, making it a neat experience experimenting with a newly discovered weapon to see how it behaves.  The bright colors and loud explosions just make the battles a fun time.

There is a lot of depth in this game, which works both for and against it.  Either you will fall in love with the systems and want to devote dozens of hours to exploring how they work, or you will get frustrated at the lack of direction and quit.  The game has an interesting campaign mode that plays out as a sort of planetary Risk, with you and each enemy brain committing funds to different sites on the planet to explore, attack, or defend, and battles occur when you both go after the same site.  Whoever has the most money at the end of the game wins.  I would have really liked a story mode that slowly introduces the complexity to you, instead of pushing you off the deep end without any guidance.

There is a good game underneath all the complexity!  I just do not have the time it requires to really get the most out of it.  Lively cartoonish graphics combined with fun gameplay give you a decent diversion, but there are better games for short-term enjoyment.  If you are looking for a long-term single-game RTS to play for the next decade, then give Cortex Command a shot.  Encouraging news is that the game is still being updated today, and Data Realms are constantly tweaking balance issues and adding new features.  There is also a strong community dedicated to modding the game.  This is a game you can invest a lot of time into and not run out of things to do!

reviewText: You want a review? ♥♥♥♥ you, how about a recap instead?\n\nI remember Cortex Command vaguely. It's one of the earliest examples of why early access shouldn't be a thing. The game was hyped up like crazy the first few years it was available. It was hard to be on the internet in the late 00's without hearing about it. People were hyped for a strategy game that implemented complex 2D physics. However, as time went on, the creator slacked in developing the game and lashed out at people who had complaints like hey

reviewText:
First Impression:
Conceptually Excellent, I have been looking forward to buying this game for years.
I just wanted to wait until I thought it was ready for purchase.
With build 30 I decided it was finally time.
I sat down at the keyboard with nervous excitement.
I started up the game, watch a fun into video.
Giddy with excitement I clicked the campaign, (not finished no biggie), and started the tutorial. Within seconds my excitement starts to falter, then fade.  I immediately realize that this game is only playable on a console or with a controller even though I selected mouse and keyboard controls.
A few minutes later I find out that the controls are even worse then I imagined.  The same commands given over and over give different results. Pushing up and right to fire the jetpack will sometimes move you up and right, other times it will hover you in place, other times it will move you straight up.  The list goes on.  After playing for 10 minutes and accidently turning on the ai of the unit I was controlling so that it would just start doing whatever it wanted and override my commands I gave up.  With a heavy heart I still wasn't ready to give up.  So I pulled out my xbox 360 controller and set it up on my computer. After a few minutes I was good to go.  I started up the game switched the controls to joystick and tried again.  After loading up the tutorial I was met with being told to do things with [][]  with no buttons inside to let me know what to do.  So Knowing I was trying to select a bot I hit every button on the controller including pushing down the movement sticks, yet none of the buttons slected the bots.  So with all my dreams crushed and the inability to deal with the horrendous controls, I step back and write this review to warn others.
I plan on coming back to the game next update and giving it another try, if things change I will update this review.

reviewText:
I really want to like this game, but it's borderline unplayable on OSX. If some of the major issues get addressed, I'd be really excited to play, but at the moment I'm spending most of my time wanting to rip my hair out.  The idea of the game is REALLY cool, and yes, I had fun playing, but mostly it was an exercise in frustration.

These are the major issues that I encountered:

1. Broken 360 controller support. Buttons work, but not the sticks.

2. Godawful frame rate at any resolution.

3. Screen resolution options are terrible with anything other than native screen res. Smaller resolution in a window is very tiny, and going full-screen doesn't actually fill the screen, it just makes the same size window" in a full-screen. That means lots of black with a still-tiny game in the middle.

4. Fonts - anything smaller than native resolution (1680x1050 in my case) is unreadable.

5. The aiming system is very difficult. Sometimes I get an aiming "reticle" so I can see where I'm aiming across the screen
date: but other times (even with the same gun) it's not there
recommended: which means you can't tell where you're aiming except to carefully watch the bullets.\n\n6. The jet-packs - after 2 hours of play-time
hoursPlayed: I still can't get my soldiers around using the jet-packs. Most of the time
voteText: they seem to barely budge my soldier off the ground. If a soldier gets stuck down a mine-shaft (or whatever)
helpfulPercent: it takes so much time to get them back out that the rest of my squad is usually wiped out. Consequently
votesHelpful: I end up leaving many squad members in useless positions and buying more."

reviewText: The game had potential, it really did. As it stands though the final product, if you can call this a final product, is not passable. The user interface is downright poor and for this game's concept to work it would need a fantastic interface. At the end of the day I might have been able to put up with the frequent crashes and lack of game modes and content in general if the interface were more intuitive but it simply isn't up to snuff. Without a way to quickly and easily call in reinforcements or to control those reinforcements the game just doesn't play well. It's a shame too because the games core concepts and mechanics are promising. Final verdict is that this game isn't worth the money even on sale.

reviewText: Very confusing UI and lack of customization for windowed modes. Also, it has a steep difficulty curve, and while challenge is nice, the game has no sense of pacing, so right away you're screwed over.\n\nA little clarity: it's basically a mix between tower defense and platforming combat. I don't know how to describe it, but the only word I can't use is -good-. See, there's very little room for error, and the game unfortunately makes you mess up tons of times. When controlling basic characters you'l often find yourself flapping around because of poor controls, and your guy will be sent flying to a part of the map you don't want. Other times the jetpack will just die on you, leaving your character to die.  As far as engagements go, you fight guys on the ground with ranged weaponry, but you and them are made of paper, so you die almost instantly when one sees the other. Even the tutorial is unforgiving like this, and you'll die if you don't shoot him the second he comes on screen. So above all, I would avoid this game, even on sale, unless you're intothe type of game I described. I wish I didn't have to be so harsh, but there is one last thing that really bugs me: no single player that I'm aware of. You get to play multiplayer versus bots, and online if I recall, but Im not too much into those, and for 15 bucks I was kinda hoping for it. Maybe I didn't look hard enough, but what can you do?

reviewText: Quite an entertaining engine and sandbox, with all manner of visceral pixel destruction physics. Quite admirable in that respect. I'm not sure how many sandboxy options are actually afforded to you anymore, that was from much earlier in development, and I'm sorry to say that the actual game portion of the game, in spite of continued revamps, just isn't even remotely engaging on an actually-playing-the-game level. It's remarkable fun to watch ♥♥♥♥ get destroyed, particularly dropships, but actually attempting to control stuff and do battle is an impossibly obtuse and clunky process. Even from its earliest days in development I was entertained with the engine, but really could not imagine how they intended to build a game around it.\n\nI'm still not sure that they did.

reviewText:
Quite possibly the most perfect example of unrealized potential.

Cortex Command feels very much like a pet project that some developer put a lot of love and effort to make a freeware linux game in which it'd be possible to overlook every single one of these flaws. But the price is $20! It might be worth $5 to play in the sandbox and see what might have been.

The control scheme is so incredibly broken - for every action except movement and cycling between your forces, you need to navigate a radial menu. Reloading? Switching weapons? Buying more troops? RADIAL MENU. The control of aiming is almost impossible with a mouse or keyboard - gamepad is effectively a requirement.

Menu navigation in the middle of an action game is just such a huge no no.

reviewText: If There was anything that was funny in a game, its making  funny moments in a review. #10 deflecting a deystroyer shot with a lightsaber ( And killing my own brain.. -.- ) #9 Mods mods mods... where to get started? (Very good mod, get now. ) #8 Buying an overpowered battleship from a mod and crashing it into the enemy's safespot.#7Probably the Hueg Pack of mods mod... The reflective sphere of course! wait, you haven't heard yet? its controlled by Lua and boss.( invincible? ) #6 The loyaltists... millitia + rebels... Good for a 300 oz tank...(premade soldiers can help you alot. )#5 ( 50% done ! ) The Ul-Tex mod. Bombs, 500kg of course. 5 1/2 The nuke mod. adds in alot of op bombs... and blackholes. and lasers.and map wipes. Who cares ? #4 Air support mod, actually armed flying machines, PLUS AA guns. 4 1/2, Megalodon helicopter, VERY easily deystroyed but very op when used correctly.#3 The imperium of man... Ah, where do i begin... Oh yeah, maltaguns. Lazer beams of destruction... ( A shoop dah Woop in a gun.) #2 The crabs.CRAAAAAAAABS ( And the legend of Zalo of course ) Mother crabs, mother mother crabs... Giant soldiers.. ahh.... memories. #1 What you've all been waiting for....... The actor of the year goes to.... Randal the shootinator!!! ( reference to a youtuber..) For real now, the funniest moment would be shooting down a grenade midair, above your brain, that happens to be a flare, just in time covering him in concrete, and a stack of dead crabs.... ( Very good tactical strategy to use crabs as bombs. 20 oz for a crab crate... ( MOD IDEA 2015! )\nOkay. well there goes about a good 5 minutes of writing a review a paragraph or two long. reviewText:
Cortex Command is a physics-based strategy-shooter. With much more physics than most other games you'll see out there, and the highest level of modability I've ever seen.

It's difficult to say who will like this game or not. Honestly, it is. I know that I like it a lot. What I do know is that you might like this if you like: shooters, particle physics simulations, RTS, and blowing stuff up. The best way to figure out whether you should buy it is by watching gameplay videos so you know what it's all about beforehand.

There is a catch, though: the game is single-threaded, meaning you need to have a decent processor to play this game at a reasonable speed, so don't get this if your only computer is an old laptop.

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: This is one of the coolest games I have played lately..  I really enjoyed this game a lot so far and pretty much love everything about it.  Definitely not the sort of gameplay for everyone, there is a blend of action and strategy.  The physics engine in this game is like nothing I have ever really seen before, and it is rather impressive.  Even more impressive is the devs next game engine already in the works.   You can make modifications for this game, and even your own totally custom levels with some additional programs.  The built in editor lets you easily remake the inlcuded maps.  I just wish it would not depend so heavily on the CPU because when action gets heavy this game can slow down quite a bit.  There are ways of getting around this though, tweaks to settings files and even the possibility to make modifications.  For me these tweaks seem to have fixed the issues mostly.\n\nUpdate:  This game still rocks IMO..  I'm really surprised it has such a low meta score, and that more people aren't digging it.  It has a ton of replayability, especially with all the awesome mods.  The ONLY thing I don't like about this game is that it runs poorly on my quad core because it isn't multithreaded, but the core engine was built a long time ago and would probably be a pain in the butt to redo.  So I can accept that, especially because it is still a lot of fun.

reviewText:
Cortex Command is an odd case. Having spent much of its time in development Hell and being released on Steam in what many believe to be an incomplete state, it's not hard to understand why the game gets a bad rap.

However, underneath the bugs and quirks lies an indie title that does things quite a bit differently from others. It's not right to call it another 2D platformer or a shooter trying to be Terraria". It's something of its own.

Firstly
date: Cortex Command offers a simple and yet versatile file structure that allows an enormous range of mods. If the game bugs you one way or you want something in the game that isn't there
recommended: you're practically encouraged to do so. On its official forums
hoursPlayed: an enormous range of already-completed mods can be found
voteText: allowing those unskilled in development to pick and choose from the wealth of community additions.\n\nSecond
helpfulPercent: the game offers something distinctly different from other games. It blends strategy and action together in an odd
votesHelpful: yet enjoyable package
votesTotal: allowing the player to order new troops to fight their battles and manually take control of individual units to help swing the tide of battle. Indeed
votesFunny: it is entirely possible to win most scenarios by picking the right selection of equipment and going it alone - though it may be quite difficult
commentsCount: especially if one uses the frail brain robot for this task.\nDetailed terrain deformation and physics offer creative ways of manipulating the battlefield or assaulting enemy positions
column16: where literally everything can be blasted
column18: or bashed open with the right tools. Roughly everything is physically simulated
column19: from sprays of dirt from a mining tool to an infantryman's legs in motion and even the debris from a destroyed aircraft.\n\nWhich brings us to my third point. Cortex Command is
column21: comedy gold at times. Fighting off an enemy invasion with an armless and legless meatball of a man
column22: using his sheer weight as his weapon
column23: is entirely possible. Crashing a dropship full of crabs into a well-planned defensive wall and watching the gibs from the explosion kill everything in a half-mile radius is more than an infrequent occurrence - even if crabs aren't buyable in the campaign anymore. And with mods
column25: particularly when they go catastrophically wrong.\n\nWhile a bit pricey for its simplicity
column26: Cortex Command is still a game I'm happy to have purchased. There is one thing everyone should note before they take the plunge
column27: however: Most agree that this is not a game for everyone and opinions are typically black and white; you either love it to death or hate it with a fiery passion. Try to get first-hand accounts about the game from both sides of the fence before making your final decision. And if you do buy the game
column28: I do hope you enjoy it."

reviewText:
This game is a buggy mess, if you lose a battle under certain conditions, the resource meter actually ticks negative PAST 0 and defaults to the maximum value, giving you a ludicrous amount of cash. Some times your brainbot that you just landed on a planet right next to your standard air defense drone starts digging while you're in buy mode (Which is fine since you told it to do that) and then randomly EXPLODES for no reason, resulting in instant death.

And let's not even talk of how precise the AI is with tagging rockets with grenades.

It's a buggy erratic mess, but it's still fun.

And I suppose it will take another ten years to get all the bugs out. If you can deal with the fact that this game has more bugs than Liero despite probably having a bigger budget, then sure I recommend it.

Otherwise go get Liero for free, and blow up some worms.

reviewText:
I recommend this game because:
You never know what's going to happen next. Someone could shoot a weapon right out of your hand, and and the weapon hits the person behind you. Or someone could shoot down an airship, only for the debris to fall on the people below and smash them. The physics engine is amazingly detailed, but you need to watch out.
Also the game is fully moddable, so you could get yourself some kind of nuclear bomb shooter... or weapons from DayZ! (The game is a lot more fun with mods, you'll get bored faster without them.)
Best of all, if you have Xbox 360/PS3 controllers to plug into your PC, you could play split screen with your friends, maybe on a TV if you have a cable to hook it up with. As it says, you could play 2 v 2, 3 vs 1, 1 v 1, 4 vs CPU, etc..
The only downside is that this game needs to be updated more often, since the game needs to be a little polished.

reviewText: This is an utter failure. This game only works right on winXP, any more modern machine and you not only can't go fullscreen, you're stuck  squinting at 4-pixel high text in a tiny window. So many great ideas seem to be waiting for you to find them past the showstopper bugs - but a quick trip to the forum tells you about layer after layer of showstopper bugs. This should not have shipped, it should not be on steam.

reviewText: This game is brilliant! absolutely brilliant. If you love rts's, building games like terraria, and shooters this game is for you!!! it has an awesome tactical campaign mode where you plan the invasion of a planet turn by turn, and then the battles zoom in for the real time part, you design your base with a TON of parts, rooms, defenses, vehicles, weapon stashes, everything you can think of, and plan the invasion of the other players sites. It's all in all absolutely brilliant, and just goes to show inovative gameplay doesnt have to be wrapped up in a shiny polished hi def graphics game, imo this game brings a ton of innovations to the strategy genre.

reviewText: I've been playing this game for YEARS, and now it finally has a full release. And it's better than I ever thought it'd be. The campaign is not 100% polished, but man is it fun. The AI puts up a great fight, now, rather than an overwhelming, unwinnable challenge. The amount of weapons you can get is insane. The modding support is amazing. Basically, this is a game I didn't know I needed until I chanced upon it several years ago. Since, I've been eager to get my hands on this full release and it's as good as I ever hoped.

reviewText:
One of the most creative and innovative games I have ever played. I bought this a few years ago and this still sits as one of my favorite games.

There is a fairly large learning curb, as I can't even compare the gameplay to any other games. The closet I can compare it to is that this is like Wurms turned real-time with an overdose of action, a massive hit of strategy, and under all of that is a tab of freedom.

There is a health bar, but most of the time it means nothing besides a bleedout timer as you can be instantly killed by a headshot or be crushed to death by your own dropship or rocket. You can shoot off legs and arms and sometimes it can even works towards your favor, but most of the time it doesnt as you hands to even hold a gun.

Did your space rambo get both of his legs blown off and is rapidly bleeding to death? No worries, without those legs weighing you down you can jetpack much faster towards the enemies and then headbutt people to death as you fire your machinegun. But wait, as you move forward a stray piece of dropship debris hits you at 666km/h, killing you instantly. You are quickly overwhelmed by crash-test dummies with spacey nailguns and kills your disembodied brain because you spent all of that money on rambo and didnt bother investing in gold mining. All that is left is a fail message cycling through your screen.

tl;dr Buy it.

reviewText:
*Radio transmission* Ronin dropship inbound *Over*
*Radio transmission* Take it down soldier! *Over*
*Radio transmission* Sir! We need reinforcement! Corpses of crabs smashed through our frontlines *Over*

These are the positive things with the game.
+Physics, Anything in the game can kill you, debris, corpses and flying weapons
+Pretty awesome selection of weapons for factions such as Ronin, Coalition and Dummy
+No unkillable late game ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t
+Turrets are really not that great in certain terain

These are stuff that can be improved.
*Turrets require a concrete floor to walk on in some maps to be decent
*some nation lack decent weaponry
*Wish it would be more machinery and turrets available
*Some kind of unit level for those champion guys that refuse to die after 40 min of constant killing

Negative stuff that need to be fixed
*terrain are way to soft and you very likely to get stuck with turrets on flat maps
*lack of blast protection
*fortfication not really protecting units
*AI not getting additional gold miners aside from the brain so after  all money is spent the unit flow reduces drastically

I'm looking so forward for future updates

reviewText:
I first played Cortex Command back in 2007, a demo for it was on a CD that came with MaximumPC magazine. The game was build 18 back at that time. I had a blast with it then for quite awhile, then forgot about it. Then in 2009 I rediscovered it, but found out that there was a ton of mods available for the game. I remember coming home from school day after day and just playing skirmish against the AI outfitted with modded weapons and characters on custom maps, I must have racked up at least 300 hours in the game, if not more. It was seriously the only game I played for a few months (hey, I had dial-up internet at the time and not a lot of money, I can't really complain)

Some things you might find useful:

This game loads all the files upfront, similar to Kerbal Space Program. The more mods you have, the longer it will take to load. Games like this REALLY benefit from being on a SSD or ramdisk. A ramdisk might not be necessary, but it depends on how much you play it, how often you reboot and how often it crashes on you.

If you want a nice fullscreen borderless windowed setting for a 1920x1080 monitor, open up Cortex Command/Base.rte/Settings.ini and set ResolutionX to 960 and ResolutionY to 532, Fullscreen to 0, NxWindowed to 2 and NxFullscreen to 2. Then run the below .ahk file with AutoHotkey (or use the .exe version) and press Ctrl+Alt+G to remove the window's borders.
If you don't have a 1920x1080 monitor, setting ResolutionX to half your horizontal resolution and ResolutionY to 8 subtracted from half your vertical resolution should work, but I don't have any other monitors to test it with. If stuff is too small on screen, you could try setting NxWindowed to 3 and set ResolutionX to 1/3 your horizontal resolution and ResolutionY to 6 subtracted from 1/3 your vertical resolution. If you have amazing eyes and want everything to appear at its original resolution (unzoomed) then set NxWindowed to 0, ResolutionX to your horizontal resolution, and ResolutionY to 16 subtracted from your full vertical resolution, but be aware that this is quite hard to see clearly, and is probably best for HDTVs or very large monitors.
AutoHotkey script: https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/25140621/fullscreen.ahk
https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/25140621/fullscreen.exe

Spacebar or escape will skip the startup message and intro. Don't accidentally hit escape at the main menu or the game will close (which could mean sitting through another long loading sequence). Setting PlayIntro to 0 in Settings.ini will just throw you straight into the tutorial mission, so you could do that too I suppose.

If you ever want more money in the middle of a mission, press tilde (`) to open the console and paste in:
ActivityMan:GetActivity():SetTeamFunds(5000,0)
Feel free to replace 5000 with however much money you want.

And in case you were curious, my favorite mods from back in the day were/are AAL by numgun, DarkStorm by Darlos9D, UniTec by Gotcha! and Crobotech by capnbubs. UniTec has a massive assortment of items and characters, as well as some nice mechs. DarkStorm has a bunch incredibly innovative scripted items and characters which are a ton of fun. AAL has pretty nice heavy soldiers and a giant mecha with a big variety of weapons (however it's quite unbalanced), and Crobotech has some very fun polished weapons and characters (also relatively unbalanced).

reviewText:
I'm trying really hard to like this game, because it combines so many elements that I usually love: it's a sandbox (or rather box of toy soldiers) full of cool stuff with crazy physics, ragdoll soldiers, a totally destructible envirnoment... and yet somehow it seems to add up to less than the sum of its parts. Here are a list of some of my grievances:

1) The controls, UI, menus etc are all very ropey and unintuitive. It takes a long time to get a basic grasp on stuff like the RMB command dial and the jetpacks for moving around, and the worst thing is almost nothing is explained to you, so you just have to persevere and figure it out. Now, I'm old enough that I grew up with games that were like this by deafault, but I think most modern gamers would find the lack of a proper tutorial inexcusable and annoying.

2) The load time for the game is ridiculous; it's literally the longest-loading game I own by some distance. This game is a 90Mb download... how can it take longer to load than massive, graphics-intensive games? I feel like I haven't waited this long for a game to load since the days when I owned an Amiga 500!

3) So many crashes, so much lag caused by too much stuff happening on screen. It crashes enough without mods, but with mods I can barely finish a scenario without an unexplained CTD or hang. Given the game's modding community is one of the things people praise about it, this seems prety unforgivable.

4) Absolutely no story, nothing to work for, no progression. It even has a paltry 11 Steam achievements! I know it's a sandbox, but I feel like a structured campaign where you were slowly immersed in the game, unlocking weapons etc as you went, would make it a lot less overwhelming and keep you engaged for longer.

5) Starts to feel very samey very quickly, despite the obvious diversity of units and weapons on offer.

I'm only 7 hours in an debating whether I will put much more time into this, if I'm honest. I got it at 80% off and I guess I've had my £3 worth of entertainment from it already, but there's absolutely no way I could recommend this at full price. Pick it up on sale if you fancy messing around with it for a few hours, but don't expect a game that you'll love. It's a shame, as I really wanted to love it!

reviewText:
Pretty much one of my favorite games of all time (and I haven’t even touched the multiplayer). It's a lot of fun with a fully destructible voxel environment and surprisingly detailed projectile simulation and damage modeling. Controls can be hard to learn at first but when you master them you don’t forget them I just came back to this game after a year and I was still great with the jetpack. Finally with it’s healthy mod community (including two core gameplay-overhaul mods) you can count on months of fun at the very least!

TLDR: Very fun, lots of mods...

10/10
